[size=12][COLOR=#009900][b]MIKE'S[/b][/COLOR][/size]

RATING: 9
Rating after 1 play of a 2 player game.
It was fun. It was chaos. And that with only 2 players.
It took longer than expected, but I loved it.  I can see how with a lot of players/a long map it could get frustrating/incredibly long, but I'd still like to give that a go.

Second game with 7 players.  We didn't finish.  But it was fun.  I realised it probably isn't a good idea to sabotage your robot with a load of red wine. It really doesn't work as well.

Have played quite a lot now and just really think it is a great fun game.  Just played a short, deadly, 6 player game.  Only 2 survived.  Loads of fun.
Upgraded to a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm drawn to racing games but there are very few good ones.  Robo Rally is the best racing game I've played, and a great game in general.  Puzzling out the most efficient use of cards while trying to predict where your opponents are going to end up makes for a fun a challenging game.

There is a learning curve regarding being able to visualize where the cards in your hand will land you on the board.  Until you know how to drive your robot it's best if you stick to simple one board tracks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I am thinking of using this game in a robotics workshop I run for high schoolers, to introduce programming in an informal way.

RATING: 7
Great fun, especially when players are close enough that they influence each other. Occasionally, a player can get off to a fast start (thanks to the luck factor involved) which reduces interactivity, but all of the games I've played have been fairly close at the end, so I'm not sure it's that big of a problem. The game can be extremely frantic, and player elimination can become a problem, so it's probably best to take this game in limited amounts

RATING: 7.5
It's like Logo (that old kid's computer programming language, remember?), only now your turtle is a killer robot, racing towards the final goal.

Fun, and easy to get confused due to turns and board interaction (there are things that turn and move you on the board, as well as other robots that can push you around).

RATING: 6
Lovely game in many ways - actually better with more players. Fun-loving, but not terribly strategic. For a good time, it's good. For a good game it's.... feh. My variant now is to play one card at a time. Sure, it's really easy, but it removes the frustration of this game and still maintains the fun at least for me. Feels more strategic too and substantially less chaotic. Sold it.

RATING: 6
2009-01-12
Again, here's a game that is at its best with more players due to the chaotic nature of the game.

2016-05-24
Robo Rally is one of those games in which the journey is more important than destination. This is due to the extremely chaotic nature of the game. Your plans are most guaranteed to fail.

But the magic of the game is in failing. It is like throwing things down into a gorge just to see what happens. For non-serious gamers Robo Rally offers great laughs and fun.

RATING: N/A
Can't really give it a good rating as I've only played one game.  

Interesting premise.  Several programmer friends of mine love the game, and so a friend of a friend brought it out and we finally got to play it.  They said that all programmers love it... but my husband wasn't too thrilled by it.  Sure, you "program" your robot, but the entire game is about spacial awareness.  I'm great at that... my husband, not so much.  

The game would have gone better if all of us had been allowed to read the rules.  Two of the people playing had played it many times before, and three of us (me included) had never played it before.  We would have benefited from having more things explained.  But that is not a failing of the game, so much as a failing of the people we were playing with...

That said, my husband and I didn't do too poorly.  We were playing the "tag the flag" gametype where we had to go from one flag to another, in order from one to three, and the first bot to reach three would win.  Everyone in the game at least made it to the second flag.  Some of us got almost to three.  And again, would have been better if we had known more of the rules.

Hopefully next time (if there is a next time) will be better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This reminds me of a cross between the Hannah Barbara racing cartoon and the movie short circuits Johnny 5. It was the game Richard Garfield was pitching without success when he ended up having to fall back on his backup prototype a little game known as mtg. Robo Rally is about a crazy robot race through a series of modular boards with different kinds of obstacles and environmental conditions in order to be the first bot to take flags in each board in sequential order. The catch is you have to program your bots and then execute the actions in order so this leads to all kinds of crazy shenanigans. Especially when you damage other robots and start locking certain commands into their tableu. Robo rally is a good racing game. As far as race games go, I think it is probably one of the better ones.

RATING: 6
(Sold to make room on my shelves.)

A fun game that always gets laughter at the table.  Plays better with more players.  There's a little bit of a problem with runaway leaders, though.  If someone can break away from the pack, they'll have a much easier time for the rest of the game.

Update: I've had to bump this down to a 6 for my group.  The runaway leader is a huge problem with the number of players we are able to bring together.  Maybe if we could get more to the table, it would be harder to break away from the pack.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
very good simultaneous action game, but it takes a little bit too long for most people.
Some also say that it is too random since you cannot possibly know where others are going to end up. Although I'll admit it is pretty chaotic at times, the same people always win. You simply need to take every other player into account when planning your phase ahead, making this a very strategic game indeed.
My point being; don't let yourself be convinced by those don't like it, 'cause actually it's a gem.

Theme (artwork/story/...)
2/2
Gameplay (smooth play/player interaction/strategy&tactics/depth)
4/5
Fun factor (can you afford a smile during play?)
2.5/3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game has the distinction of now being my least favorite game with any sort of reputation, bumping Galaxy Trucker out of that position. First off, I'm absolutely horrible at the game - I somehow programmed my robot to jump off the board in the same place twice without having anyone change my direction or interfere with my orders. I just don't seem to be able to wrap my head around the conveyor belt and how it rotates your direction at the corners. I was also the first one to take three lives before anyone took even one. And even with a pity extra life, I was still way out of the running, and still moving away from the target flag. However, I would also say that this game is completely chaotic with no way of really being able to plan where you want to go even if you could properly visualize where you want to go. I'm sure there is a first-run, small time game by some unknown publisher out there that I dislike more than RoboRally, but I just can't think of what that is. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When I play this, I prefer the variant where you start out with an option card, and get a new one at each checkpoint.

The main problem with this game is that the example set-up in the rules is horribly flawed, leading to lengthy games with a run-away leader problem. But if you don't realize that, and design all your courses that way, the game becomes a lengthy exercise in frustration, ultimately tossed in the closet.

Hopefully, the upcoming reprints will have some sanely-designed sample courses.

RATING: 7
Race
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The game's strength is it's tactical level.  You'll try to use the actions you have available to you to move yourself towards your goal, maybe by riding on a conveyor belt or sitting on a turning platform to save a few actions.  You know which actions are going to execute in which order, so once you have your hand of actions, play is entirely determined by your decisions.

The exception to this, of course, is if one of the other players makes a move that affects your path.  If a bot ends the register (after each robot has executed that order, and after the terrain has triggered) facing another bot, it will be able to attack with a laser.  If a bot runs into another bot, it will be able to push the other bot, potentially throwing off the entire rest of the round for that player.  This is an interesting aspect, and the only thing that stops it from being a pure race, but whether or not you'll be a RoboBully or a RoboVictim comes down to whether you happen to start the round close to another bot (which usually happens incidentally, as "Destroy all other bots" isn't usually the goal), and whether you get closer to the cards you need than they do (which comes down to pure, dumb luck).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
  A great game of planning and programming a robot in a race to checkpoints, the first robot to the last checkpoint wins.

  Each player has 9 cards with move orders on them; Move forward, turn left, turn right, u-turn etc... They then select 5 cards that will be the robots next 5 actions, then watch it play out. Mistakes are made, robots crash and shoot each other, robots end up running around in circles due to a lack of move forward cards or are stuck on conveyer belts. Brilliant, silly fun, do yourself a favour and pick up a copy :D

RATING: 8

RR is one of the few racing games in which a losing player still has a lot of fun in going through the motions, just watching adversary robots collide or fall off the board.

There's some need of spatial vision capabilities, but nothing excessive. It can be played by anyone.

RATING: 4
Interesting at first, but wears out its welcome fast. Frustrating miscalculations and difficulty preparing for what your opponents can possibly do just because there's no way of knowing what cards they have and at what initiative order. Falling through a hole in the map is just brutal.

RATING: 7
This game can suffer terribly from Analysis Paralysis.  If the supercomputer is bored, do you really think it will take 5 minutes to plot out and program a robot's movement - incorrectly?  Not likely.  This game really needs a timer on the turns and house rules for incomplete programs (i.e. cards not played in time).  When its fast and furious, the game's underlieing humor emerges and we all enjoy watching Twonky race through the hazards with his 'firiends'.  [GTI Code: TGSD]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

It could be fun if you like to throw your arms up in the air and just go with whatever happens, laughing in the chaos of it all. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think that people definitely have a love/hate relationship with this game.  This is a game for the analytical types.  Programmers will love this game because it's what they do all day long.   If you have the Wizards of the Coast edition You may need a timer to prod the AP types.  Make sure you give this game a couple of tries.  In your first game the chances are that you will be lost and trying to figure out how the game works, and you probably will go down in flames.  Also this game can go slowly if everyone is having problems getting past one tough part of the board.  Also has a tinge of the laugh at your opponents misfortune that you will find in games like Pompeii and Survive!

RATING: 8.5
This is a pretty fun programming, racing game. There is some strategy involved, but it is mostly just a lot of mayhem and foiled plans. This game provides a lot of laughs and is great for the family. It might not be the best choice for someone who gets angry when their plans go awry. I basically view this as the gamer's version of a party game. There is an actual game to play, but the value of the game comes primarily from the laughs and the chaos.

RATING: 7.5
Great game - lovely components and superb game play.

Programming your robots from your hand of cards and then watching them get knocked off course by your opponents is hugely entertaining. (It's even better when you do unto your opponents before they do it to you!)

The various expansions add extra hazards to the game.

Great as a two player game but even better with more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Played several times with various expansions and variant rules. What the game is, and how it feels like, is determined a lot by these, so it's hard to give a rating for just the base game. Love the concept, sometimes love the gameplay, but in the end, I feel there's too few truly meaningful decisions over the course of the average game for this game to really shine. Mostly you're just trying to see the most optimal pattern in your set of cards given your position on the board (which just takes time), hoping you didn't make any mistakes, and only once or twice per game do you get to second guess your opponents. Those are the moments when the game shines, but it's too little for the amount of time a game can take. Gets significantly better with more players, as then there's more chances of more of these moments, and the added chaos makes the game more fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

That said, RoboRally is just plain fun.  The mechanics of "programming" your little bot and watching him bash his way through the factory floor feels unique and is totally entertaining.  It's not the most strategic game but it always seems to elicit plenty of laughter and smiles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Hilarious if playing with non-gamers who are directionally challenged.  Really fun for the first hour... gets old if the game doesn't end quickly.  If you do plan on playing RoboRally make sure to only use one board and 2 flags.  Otherwise you could be in for a very long, boring evening.  

I have both the Avalon Hill version and the WOTC version with the Armed & Dangerous and Crash & Burn expansions.  I prefer blending the best of both versions.  I'm glad they did away with "virtual" robots.  The starting docks are the way to go. 

RoboRally is more fun for players who design their own courses, tweak the rules, come up with creative variants, and/or customize the components.  I always play with the Dealer Variant.  

Dealer Variant:
http://boardgamegeek.com/article/1243444#1243444

RATING: 7
12/31/06

One play with eight.

Even though it took a little longer than hoped and therefore were not able to completely finish the game I really enjoyed it.  It comes with a timer for a reason...  use it!

Trying to get your robot through a factory with tonnes of pitfalls including lasers, other robots with lasers, black holes of death, automated walkways and spinning thingys.   You lay out your route of five moves and then chaos ensues.  A whole lot of fun as you never really know what is going to happen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Rules are relatively simple, tricky part is being able to visualize your robot's position after each order, since many locations shift your direction. Game includes various board maps that can be joined for longer games. This game is fun because you roleplay a robot trying to aviod getting killed. Strangely though I have not had any desire to play it after my half a dozen plays... and now I know why! You basically play solitaire, since your oponents actions and your own can be quite chaotic. The board is your real opponent and it can be quite unforgiving. I'll pass...

RATING: 10
Decided to upgrade this one from 9 to 10 for the reason that this can be played with almost anyone, anytime.  The flexibility of the game allows pretty simple and quick setups or more complicated and longer setups thereby allowing most anybody's gaming taste to be satisfied!

For once my wife wanted to get a game even more than me!  We both enjoy this game very much.  It can be confusing keeping track of where your robot will be going (hopefully) with your chosen five program cards, but randomness is built in through the simultaneous play anyway.  This is certainly a game to try out and see if it fits your gaming style!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's not too complex and was very easy to get the hang of. Players start each turn with 8 move cards by default. 5 of them are selected in a sequence and places face down. At the beginning of the turn all players reveal their first move card and move accordingly. After each turn where all players have made one move you take in obstacles on the course and deal out damage or do extra moves if required then all players reveal their 2nd card in their sequence and so forth until all 5 cards have been reveal. This can lead to interesting results and it's always humor in seeing your friends end up somewhere totally of course or plain (stupid). The is no permanent death but you will suffer penalties in number of cards you can chose from should your robot be destroyed. There are other ways to be encumbered by penalties aswell and the most common way is if other players are able top aim their laser your way. 

First to go through all the checkpoints on the course will win. The best thing abut it really is when your friends mess up in their move sequence or you end up in a close battle with someone to win.

RATING: 8
I now own both the older WotC version and the new AH version.  The AH version component changes are not at all bad---the robots are not as attractive as the original version, but they aren't that bad, and most are not difficult to tell apart, even unpainted.  You want to paint both the old and the new robots, of course.  I actually like the thinner boards of the new version, since this means you can cram more Robofactory third-party boards into the box.

I love the programming mechanic of this game, in combination with all the different interacting elements on the boards.  I wish I had known about and played this game in college---I would have loved it.

Here's hoping they put out an expansion a la Armed & Dangerous for the new version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
RoboRally is a race game.  On each turn players program their robot to execute five movement actions.  Each robot then executes the pre-programmed movement actions simultaneously.  As the movement actions are executed the robots interact with each other in unexpected ways that impact the robots program and location on the map.

RoboRally is a truly unique game.  It is a lot of fun to play.  It scales well with a large number of players (very little down time is added with larger groups of people).

I prefer the one map scenarios with fewer objectives (game can be a little long (for what it is) with larger scenarios).

Good fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like this game, and it's a treat in my collection as it is quite unique. As a computer programmer and a spacial person, this game pushes all my buttons :-P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So far, I have only played this twice both times with six people.  We played a single factory floor board with 4 flags each time.  It was a lot of fun and really chaotic.  It's a lot tougher to hit those flags with so many people going for them than I initially thought.  The game ran about two hours each time, and I can see how it could last much longer with more floor boards or people.  All in all it was a lot of fun with a lot of laughs, although I could see how it could possibly drag on.  Everyone seemed to have a good time playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've loved the idea of programmed movement ever since my cousin introduced me to his Big Trak programmable car in the 80s.  I find it cool that you have to think multiple steps in advance where you will be and how you'll want to turn at that moment.  This game delivers that experience to me in board game form.  I also like the somewhat chaotic element added by the board effects, the other robots bumping you, and some other special cards.  All around this seems like a fun game that could possibly go up in rating if I play it more.  The only problem for me is that I actually played Space Alert before this game, and I just like the cooperative aspect and the time-crunch in that game better.  So I can't see Roborally ever reaching my list of favorite games, because it won't measure up to the one that came years later.

RATING: 7

After the first player has reached a certain flag, maybe give everyone else Upgrades.  Sort of like in Mario Kart.

It's easy to learn and teach.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
fun game all around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Roborally is an allegory of techonology: on a theoretical level everything works fine but then, when put into practice, something always goes wrong and nobody - not even its engineer - knows what or why it did for there’s no way to patch it up.

The same happens with Roborally: when the game starts it’s chaos rampant, thus playing may become frustrating very quickly. [i](September 2011).[/i]

[b]Update I[/b] - After trying Roborally in its full splendour (eight players) I had to make up my mind: it’s a hit! Since then, playing this game has been a completely different experience for me: now I can both fully enjoy the game and see what I missed once. 

This is, where all the fun lies: chaos, confusion and heavy interaction among players, which is exactly what I look for in a game. I wonder how I could miss to notice it before.
Thus, rating raised from 5 to 8. [i](June 2012)[/i]

[b]Update II[/b] - I just can’t get Robororally off my mind. I keep playing it over and over, enjoying it more and more: it’s both fun and a sure hit with my friends, even more so when playing with a large group. As a matter of fact I enjoy chaos in a game and Roborally carries out this task excellently, as it keeps everything simple whilst spawning an overwhelming mess on the board.

In my opinion, but one trick is needed to let this game give its best: simply allow any player to activate the hourglass as soon as he feels like during the programming phase. This will make both the cards choosing more agitated and funny events on the board more frequent.

That being stated, this game deserves a full 10, the third time I’ve rated a game so high. [i](January 2013)[/i]

[b]Update III[/b] - Over the years something happened and now Roborally doesn’t shine as much as it did lately: actually, I’m ashamed to say that lately, when offered to play it, I even started skipping it in favor for other games.

Somehow I’m not feeling attracted to playing it anymore, which in October 2017 led me to lower my rating from 10 to 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Chaotic past the point of fun. It gets a five only because it's well designed and I may actually give it one more try in a far and distant future.

Update: I'm softening up on this one, but it's still only fun up to a point and that's usually about half way to game's end.

RATING: 8
[Tanga purchase.]
This game is just pure fun. One of the few games that I don't care if I win or lose; it's all about the playing. It's pretty much impossible to plan a strategy, because you're at the mercy of the cards you're dealt. I don't usually like that, but like I said, this game is all about the experience--I just LOVE this game.

RATING: 7
Significantly more fun when you come up with your own rules variant that keeps players all roughly in the same area. Racing from board to board to board results in very low player interaction.

Idea: 4 flag points, one per corner of a single board. First player to end a turn on each flag in any order wins.

Idea: The center 16 squares are the safe zone. Ending your turn outside the safe zone results in two points of damage. Last robot standing wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fairly light and fun game of robot racing and fighting. The hook is preogramming your 'bots and hoping that they do what you want them to do-- which depends on the vagaries of other players and obstacles on the map. Can be confusing for some players, especially newer gamers, since you have to consider where you want your 'bot to be based on the cards you hold, what other bots are likely to do, and how to overcome obstacles in your way. This can lead to analysis paralysis and can make games last a bit long. The newer edition has a timer (which helps), suggested map layouts (even better), and a starting board that eliminates the old, complex "virtual 'bot" rules. Upgraded for the addition of a timer and suggested map layouts in the latest edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Use variant rules to shorten game, and give more control.
Players get 1 card more than usual.  All players can do 1 re-compile a turn (Upgrade allows recompile for free).  Fire Control can only disable an upgrade for the remainder of the turn.
Deal 3 upgrades, choose 1, at start of game.
Discard 1/2 (round up) upgrades on death.  If this reduces to zero, then get a new one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I get with this game is trying to be, but it's basic design is fundamentally flawed. Players focus should fundamentally be about tactically navigating the obstacles and other players, and finding delight and horror in the unexpected results of their carefully laid plans--er, programs. It's a great premise.

But instead, because the results of the execution are entirely make or break, and the game is structured with nether wiggle room nor time pressure, players and up having to focus on tediously analyzing every sequence of moves. This is especially glaring when it comes to rotating conveyor belts, since the specific sequence of when you reach a square and when it turns you has such a profound impact. That means that instead of racing across the stage in a state of flow, the game continually grinds to a halt so that players don't experience frustrating, pointless mistakes of anticipating the precise order with which different pressures are applied.

I don't have a clear fix, but if this were my game, I would continue to develop it and experiment with elements of chance and error correction so that there is still depth of tactics and risk of failure, but less danger of being tripped up by an edge case of the order with which events are executed within a turn. I think you should also completely get rid of turning conveyor belts.

I would also do some work to expand the range of boards and scenarios. the very simplest boards would take a group of three players more than an hour of painstaking move execution to get through. Why not have a few radically simple starter boards?

A promising game, just not really a finished one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game for large groups. Easily accessible for non-gamers.

RATING: 6.5
So many people I know hate this game and refuse to play it.  As such, it rarely gets played.  I find it best to play this with individuals who just want to have fun and don't need to have an absolute master plan.  Master planners tend to hate the game as someone will inadvertently mess a route up.  Also, the game has a runaway leader problem if too many flags are used.

Keep the flag limit down and keep the board limit down to keep the game from being stale and long.

Works very well with children, they get excited playing and it is great fun.

You get to help him stumble through all sorts of dangerous conveyors and obstacles to be the first to dock at 3 different stations.  If you plan better than the others you win, if not you end up with a whimpering pile of bolts on your hand.

This game i beleive should be played with a one minute hour glass to add intensity and excitement.  If not a person slow at reading his card options will make this game dull.

A great game for people that have a sense of humor and can et into an industrial theme.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Because of the modular boards, this game has quite a bit of replayability. Even though it is super-light, some of the funniest board gaming moments I have ever experienced have occurred in this game. The satisfaction of pushing a robot one step off-course, and then watching it accidentally plummet to its doom is satisfying! It's a special kind of joy that you can only really get from Roborally.

VERDICT:

Regardless of my numerical score for this game, if you don't own it, you need to. It's the perfect game for when you have a large-ish group that just wants to go nuts for a game or two. It gets old because of a lack of depth, but it's hard to not come back to the fields of robot destruction, time and time again.

7.5/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is so much fun to play: it's almost as much fun to win as it is to lose, or to make another player lose (accidentally or on purpose *evil grin*).

And while it's great to play just for the experience, it's also possible to play skillfully. Think about the possible moves of the other robots when planning your move, and you will get pushed and shot much less than other robots. Take advantage of the board and always plan one turn ahead, considering the possibility of drawing a hand with limited options (e.g. no turns) and then the game won't be as luck-based as it might seem at first.

[microbadge=29037][microbadge=21140][microbadge=2290][microbadge=29024][microbadge=16815]

RATING: 7.5
Only played once. Chaotic race game with robots, lasers and conveyor belts. Each turn you plan your next five moves. But if you get it wrong or someone pushes you off course anything can happen. As your robot becomes more damaged you get fewer cards to choose from making your moves harder to do, and eventually your final moves become locked in until you shutdown for a turn (and leave yourself at the mercy of the other players) or die. Great fun. Probably insane fun while drunk.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is an EXCELLENT game. However, if you lack good visual-spacial skill, you'll fail miserably and find the game frustrating. You have to be able to visualize how a 5-step plan will play out on a board that can alter your course, speed you up, shoot you with lasers, or simply kill you in various ways. If you have a hard time being able to think of where your robot will be if it 1. turns left, 2. goes forward 3 spaces, 3. goes back 1 space, 4. does a u-turn, and 5. turns left AND take into account how the board will move, shoot, crush, push, etc your robot than the game is hard and can be frustrating and feel futile. If that's something you can do, then the game is awesome. Take the tactic of kill all other robots or race to hit each flag in order. Use your special powers to save yourself or squash your rivals. You can decide how hard and how long the game is by choosing boards with more or less ways to destroy and move you and choose how many flags your robot has to touch to win this relay race. 

This game works for competitive and non-competitive people. You can play it like a demolition derby or you can play it more like simultaneous solitaire. The goal is simple. The basic rules are simple. It's good for serious gamers and new gamers (although I recommend staying away from boards with nuclear waste and more complex boards for newbies). The old version has better pieces, but the new version has a better set up for player areas and nicer cards. We use a combo of parts from the older editions and the new edition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A pretty fun programming game, where players program their robots to do stuff based on their hand of cards each turn, and then run them to see what happens!  The goal is to race your robot around the board to several checkpoints, doing so before the other players.

Of course, there are a lot of tricks to prevent you from doing this very efficiently.  You might end up on conveyer belts, getting spun around by gears, and even pushed around and shot by other players.  Even the hand you are dealt sometimes will severely limit your ability to do anything productive for a turn.  All of these things severely mess with your plans, so often a winning player is the one who has the least amount of unfortunate stuff happen to them!

The only drawback is that the game can run pretty long and overstay it's welcome if you build too large of a course.  There is also an awful lot of fiddliness in constantly shuffling and dealing cards. I stick with the medium length examples in the rulebook, which seem just about right to me.  Anything longer, and it starts to get a bit old.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A RoboRally game can be very exciting or very disappointing/boring, depending on how the course is set. (See my personal tips below.) Furthermore I do not recommend the original rules, since even slightly damaged Robots are at such a large disadvantage that there is a runaway-leader problem. I also do not like full player elimination. See my House Rules below. Send me a PM if you like to discuss them. 

DRAWBACKS:
The basic game rules take a long time to explain and digest, but can be remembered easily enough. There is also a significant luck factor.

GOOD: Fast, competitive and fun-chaotic gameplay. 

STANDARD HOUSE-ROULES:
*Damage chits _either_ reduce available hand cards (up to four) _xor_ jam program cards (up to five) _xor_ disable/explode option cards. Usually the damaged player may decide damage placement. Damaged robots are thus more controllable and much more challenging, reducing the need for boring power-downs.
*Repair stations can be used on any phase, but never twice per round. Reduce risk of runaway for the leading player, keeping the game interesting. 
*The course must always cross itself multiple time, for example all even numbered flags on side and all uneven flags on the opposite side of the board. Try to use as few boards as possible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There is a real sense of accomplishment when you manage to get your robot where you intended considering the constraints of our hand, the environment, and the chaos of the other robots.

Unfortunately, I have trouble getting the game to the table. I think part of the problem is that people find there are too many factors in play to consider and so they make errors. Making errors isn't fun. Having to try to visualize what happens after you end your turn on the spinning things isn't something a lot of people want to do a second time. And even if I don't find it necessarily difficult, I admit it isn't what I enjoy about the game. I enjoy the unintended consequences of the human interaction, not so much the interactions with the board itself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wasn't sure how this one was going to go over, but it's probably one of the most played games in our group.

RATING: 4
This is pretty much a love it or hate it game. As for me: the more I play this, the more I dislike it. 70% of the game is desperately hoping you get the right cards. The emphasis on luck means the game can run for far too long and has players getting severely punished for things completely out of their control. Tends to have a pretty big runaway leader problem as well. Fun for those who crave chaos, very frustrating for anyone else. RAMBots is superior (and cheaper.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I tend to find extended games of RoboRally a bit tedious so we usually play with a max of two boards and three flags.  We often tweak the upgrade rules too so that they get used a little more.

RoboRally can be a bit frustrating to play unless it is with experienced players.  Many new players find it a bit of a headache trying to work out moves.  Once players grasp that, then it becomes a lot more fun.

EDIT: Having played this much more this has become a game that gets played at the majority of my gaming get-togethers.  I strongly suggest that the first player finished programming his robot sets the timer, leaving the other players with a set time to finish programming.  This increases the tension and speed of the game significantly.

RATING: 8.6
8.6:  New edition.  Yes, I know the board is more flimsy, but it serves its purpose just fine.  The inclusion of the timer (in the way it's used) and the preapproved courses book is fantastic.  The flags are better and the new player sheets make everything easier to grasp.  The games are faster paced now and just more fun.  Excellent.

7.4:  Brain-burning.  If you really feel the need to give another player a hard time, you end up playing paper, rock, scissors.  Better to just make the best play you can.  I didn't really feel the game was as much a race, as it was a personal triumph to have a complete turn go your way.  I like having to think this much though.  I think the important part is to set the game up so that you create something competitive.  I didn't have such luck my first play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I’m glad I finally got to play Roborally! It’s yet a “classic” game that you just need to have played at least once. I have now played it exactly once, and while I would like to play it again I don’t think I’m going to request it all the time, and I’m a bit sad that I wanted to like it more than I actually do. The biggest reason for this is simply that Roborally takes too long to play. 1½ hours is just too long compared to the amount of fun I get out of playing it. Yes, it’s great fun to play when your robots bump into each other and your best laid plans get destroyed because of the other players – but it’s not hilariously fun over 90+ minutes (but then again, which game is).

My other complaint about the game is that once one or two players get a lead, they have it relatively easy as they’re not constantly bumped into, so they get an easier time trying to reach a new flag etc. Mind you, I’ve only played once with 7 players, so I don’t know how it would work on a different map with fewer players, but I think it would only enhance the problem. However, the problem can be mitigated by for instance placing flag 1 and 3 close to each other and flag 2 and 4 the same in the other corner of the board or something like that; that way the robots should constantly crash into each other, so that’s what I’m planning to do in my next play.

Finally, my third and final complaint is that the card drawing is pretty random (obviously), and you can really be screwed over because of this. I don’t know what the card distribution in the game is, but I know that in our game I got quite a lot of turns and only 1 move forward in the very first turn. And in another turn I needed 1 turn left but only got forward moves and a couple of rights… I do know that the game should be taken lightly as it’s a great deal of fun, but it’s still a little annoying that the cards – and not just the other players! – can screw you over.

Anyway, having said this, I still liked Roborally quite a bit! I am definitely willing to play it a lot more, but I do think it requires at least 6 players in order to maximize the chaos and fun, and I’m rarely playing with that many players. Furthermore, as stated above I think there are a few issues of which the length of the gameplay is my biggest concern. It’s funny – and frustrating in a good way! – when your carefully laid out plans get ruined because your opponent just moved his robot into yours, pushing you that one damn space away which absolutely smashes your next 5 moves; but that’s just part of the fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

My criterion for rating games



http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder: This game feels very samey from game to game except that the unknown chaos that comes from the other player's decisions. You will never know where your robots will end up.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions.  This game has only really a few decisions to make; what cards to play in what order. However, your decisions will be wrecked by your opponents and as you lose health you lose options. Less options as you go along in the game.

3) Player interaction: Tons of interaction in this game. This is the strong point of this game. You are guaranteed to get bumped and shot by your opponents and returning the favor.

4) Components/artwork:  Great miniatures and the boards look great. Very evocative of the theme.

5) Game length/complexity:  The game lasts too long if you have more than about 3 players. The more players you have the more chaos and as one player gets close to winning the others will gang up on you and kill you thus slowing the game to a crawl at times.


Bottom line: This is a chaotic fun game to play with 3-4 players. Any more and it lasts too long. But it can be fun for a group of gamers that are not too serious about their games and don't mind losing to the blind luck of getting bumped onto a conveyor! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I admit I may have some bias since I am a computer science/robotics master's student in university, but I really, really enjoy this game.  It's always a hit at department board game nights.

Players "program" their robots to drive around a death-trap of a factory by playing instruction cards from their hand.  Naturally the robots all have lasers (and other upgrades) so even if you can't reach the objectives yourself you can at least try to prevent your opponents from doing so!

One of the best mechanics is the minute-timer; if one player is taking too long to decide on their actions you stick the timer on them.  Once the time runs out you take their remaining cards, shuffle them, and randomly fill in their remaining instructions.  It keeps the game moving, and hilarity usually ensues!

RATING: 8.63

Would love the newer version with plastic bots.

RATING: 10
An evergreen of fun. Due to the modular gameboard every game can be custumized to meet the needs of the group.
Go for a fast chaotic race on one or two boards or make a long race and use all the boards and flags. The mechanics are easy to learn, so every type of group can enjoy.
The upgrades, so called optinss, are fun and versatile. Play the standard race, or make it a death match, or team death match or capture the flag or what ever other variant that comes to your mind.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a pretty fun game. It does have a runaway leader issue and there ends up being a lot less chaotic interaction than expected, especially if you end up out in front. I think this game could be improved by making the checkpoints double back on each other to cause the lead robots to come into contact with the tailenders and encourage a little healthy leader bashing (it is needed in this game since it is like a formula 1 race without needing pitstops and without catching up to backmarkers otherwise.)

2nd game rating upped from 7 to 8. More diffiult maps rule out run away leader problems for the most part. I managed to avoid losing any "lives" but at the expense of taking my eyes off th main goal. I ran three quarters of the way around the board and powered down once keeping my robot in one piece when I should have let it die and gone after the next checkpoint.
I introduced my wife to this and though she was initially frustrated she got the hang of it quickly and soon kicked my butt and Aaron's butt. The remote control was used to great effect to kill me twice and Aaron once. Kami ended up winning with at least two lives in hand. She had also been leading the race for the flags most of the time until I passed her but got nailed so close to finished when I got cards that allowed me to go over the final checkpoint but not stop on it.
It was a fitting end to the game when Kami sent me to my doom despite being half locked up.
4th game 2 players is too few. Funny how long it takes to get to some flags then zoom you finish the other flags in no time.

Very fun and funny game.
This game needs to be played by people who are willing to go quickly. Otherwise it can be to long. A recent game felt like it was dragging a bit with 7 players. maybe a 1 minute timer should be used for every turn.
Rating wavers based on being long and slow or having runaway leader sometimes and being hilarious fun at other times.

I would like to start a local race season with money earned based on performance to be spent on upgrades or fix ups for future races.

Lachlan was surprising good at figuring out the moves in his first game and beat me with a little help.



The Axe has offered to paint my minis. YAY.

RATING: 2
3 órás, 8 fős játék után azt mondom: nagyon jól indult, nagyon nagy reményekkel vágtam neki és hatalmas csalódás lett belőle. Az első 30-40 perc izgalmas, vicces. Még mindenkinek van 7-9 kártyája, még mindenki nagyjából egy helyen van, ha valaki "meghal", visszatérve nem érzi azt, hogy annyira le lenne maradva. Ha még ugyanennyit játszva véget ért volna (bár így is nagyon rosszul álltam), akár 2-3 ponttal is többet kapott volna. Ehelyett a következő 2 óra azzal telt, hogy egymásra vártunk, nehézkes volt a játék, aki meghalt nagyon messze a többiektől éledt újra. Óriásian befolyásolta a játék kimenetelét a kézben lévő lapok...

Ami a legnagyobb hibája a játéknak: nincs eldöntve, hogy partijáték, aminek izgalmasnak, szórakoztatónak és gyorsnak kellene lenni, vagy inkább stratégia játék, aminél fontos szerepet játszik, hogy mit lépnek a többiek, de ha jó játékos vagy, meg tudod nyerni. Nos ezek semelyike nem illik a RoboRallyra. A kártyák szerencsefaktora hatalmas, akár köröket kihagysz rossz kártyákkal, sőt sok esetben "öngyilkosságot" követsz el velük... Ha ki akarsz kerülni a rossz helyzetből sokat kell agyalnod rajta, hogy milyen sorrendben játszd ki a kártyákat, ami alatt a többiek csak várakoznak, és zavaró, hogy mindenki rám vár, dehát mit tudok tenni, ha nem jó sorrendet állítok fel, kiesek, meghalok...Amennyiben 1 órás lenne, ezeket a hátrányokat elnézném neki, sőt élvezném is, de 3-4 órát (3 óra volt az elsőből a 2. pontba eljutnia az első játékosnak!!!!) rászánni egy ilyen szerencsefüggő játékra, nagyon sajnálok... 

A hangulat, a robotfigurák, a viszonylag hamar elsajátítható szabályok előnyére válnak a játéknak, de ennyi.

RATING: 1
What a depressing pile of crap. Clearly intended for the same people who manage to derive enjoyment from playing the same boring and mindless game for hours and hours and hours and then some more. Why a 1? Because there truly is no point to this game. There is no way you can think of clever tactics or strategies, this is just meaningless card drafting, organising them, and then watching your robot crash and burn thanks to the actions of other players.

RATING: 7.5
This is one of those games that I don't think is a great game mechanically, but is just oodles of fun to play.  It tends to be a love-it-or-hate-it kind of a game (generally depending on whether people can visualize their moves easily).  We always play with the house rule that you get 3 option cards to begin with and get to pick one to keep.  I do think it tends to be a game that runs long and can have a runaway leader problem, but robots battling to the death (and sometimes accidentally driving themselves into pits) is well worth playing, despite any flaws in the design.

RATING: 5
Fairly fun party game. Once someone takes the lead, they tend to run away with it for the rest of the game. For me, treating it as a party game, this doesn't kill the fun of navigating the map as long as course is short, but others may find this objectionable. 

The one problem I have with RoboRally is the constant shuffling and dealing of cards. This doesn't normally bother me in a card game like Hearts, so I'm not sure why it does in RoboRally: perhaps it's the frequency, perhaps it's due to having to work around the huge player mats and course boards, or perhaps it's the feeling that the shuffling and dealing is repeatedly interrupting a single continuous race, whereas in Hearts it punctuates distinct rounds.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
STATUS: Sold

Designer: Richard Garfield 

Publisher: Avalon Hill 

Price: R350.00

Player Count: 5-6 (best)

Notes:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Roborally is not a game involving precise control over your destiny. It is a game about laughing when things go horribly, painfully awry - perhaps to you, perhaps to others. Schadenfreude + Masochism.

On simple boards, getting where you're going is more about the luck of the draw than skill - though you can usually take potshots at those ahead of you. On complex boards, skill is [b]much[/b] more relevant, to the point where planning turns becomes rather brutal for players who are inexperienced or don't have a head for the sort of spatial planning the game requires.

This game's fun per unit time increases notably if you cap turn programming; we use 60 seconds normally, or 30 seconds for a speed game. You get many more turns in, there's less downtime, and many more mistakes are made, all of which are positives for this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Many plays on www.gametableonline.  This is great thematic game, and the programming mechanic is unique and great.  It can get a little long, but I really think this is a must have in any game collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
  Using instruction cards such as rotate left or move forward 2 spaces, program your robot to navigate through the perils of a robotic demolition derby.

RATING: 8
The classic game of programming and beating up on your fellow robots.

RATING: 7
This is a great game where you program your robots and then see where they go. A lot of people have a hard time figuring out right and left from their robots perspective, but once you get the hang of it, the game is great. It's also important to play with a small criss-crossed track so that one person doesn't get to far ahead or behind and get left out of the interaction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wonderful chaos!
I never get sick of this fantastic random chaos. The more players the better. 
Best to start with small games of no more than 3 flags on one board and build from there until you know the rough game time. 
Can occasionally blow out into mega games of attrition.

Watch for the great new player dance as they turn themselves physically to replicate their planned robot's turns ;)

RATING: 8
I have played with 2, 4, and 6.  Each time a player is added, the player interaction becomes more rich and the game play more chaotic.  All in all, more players makes for more fun.  However, there is one thing that seems common in all three groups--It's difficult to stop the leader, as you have the additional task of thwarting his/her progress (if it's even possible) while advancing yourself--the more prevalent and likely focus of your attention.

One way we've mitigated this↑ is to distribute an option to each other player when the current leader touches a flag.  This brings up another (non)issue...
Options.  Without some sort of house rule, you won't see many of these cards out on the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Fun race game with robots. The challenge is that you need to programme them in advance, but with all kinds of element moving and turning and last-but-not-least the other players bumping in to you from time to time, the robots often go in a different direction than initially planned. Also, as the robots becomes more damaged, some of his turns will be fixed until he gets repairs.

It's a game for 2-4 players and usually takes some 45-60 minutes. There are 4 different boards which you can use and combine, and start and finish plus any checkpoint can be chosen per game so every game will play differently. The box says 12+ but my son (8) plays this easily.

A few years down the road. Still like this game, but doesn't get much playtime. Therefore considering to trade this away.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pretty good multi-player race game.  One problem is that some players can get knocked out early and end up with no hope of winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I enjoyed working out how to move my robot and though Ian seemed to hate it with a passion, my enjoyment never ceased. Maybe I was heavily influenced by the fact that I was always winning though and never screwed over too badly by being pushed.

Ian's rule change - flipping the timer as soon as anyone had finished 'programming' - gave it a far more hectic feel, increased the challenge and allowed for more than a few mistakes - with often hilarious consequences.

Other than myself and Robert, none of the 6 would try it again.

There is little interaction really - as you never know where others will move, it's inefficient to try to shoot others. All that can be done is to program a route that uses your cards efficiently to get to the targets - beyond that, the game feels chaotic enough to be nearly random (though there may be some predictions that are possible).

The cards dealt can feel like the main factor in success or otherwise - damaged robots making potential screwage completely exasperating.

I could imagine even myself getting tired of the mechanics after a few games.

In retrospect, it was mainly the battle against the timer thanks to our house-rule that injected most of its appeal for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Plays: 3

RATING: 7.5

Not a perfect game but I've had fun with it so far.

RATING: 3
Classic programming race game that adds some complexity through dealing with the board's special movement tiles with some guessing of what your opponents might do. Neat components with painted metal plastic minis. Old school art style with boards, cards, and bots.

Decisions are relatively simple. Turns can be quick but the overall game is rather long. Power cards are not equal but it isn't a high strategy game.

RATING: 8
Wonderful game play and great production values.  Suffers from the fact that it can take a very long time to play a game with more than 2 map boards (and even just 2 can take some time).  Nothing beats watching people do the 'robot dance' whilst looking at their cards and trying to figure out how their robot will move. :)  The unfortunate side effect of this comedy act is that it's a sure sign that analysis paralysis is setting in for that player.  My best tip for winning this game (and for avoiding AP in the game):  plan a move which minimizes the danger to your robot, even if that means just sitting a spinning for a turn, or having to move sideways.  Having to reboot from a clone can be a huge set back.

RATING: 8
Hasbro edition. Really liking this game.  Easy rules.  Play length and difficulty is adaptable based on board selection and # of players.  There are also a ton of board combos with just the base set (8 boards!).  It's also a fun game to play, where everyone roots for their robot to do "the right thing". Lots of theme for such a simple rule-set. You really feel as if your robots are zipping and humming across the factory floor. I could see this rating go up to a 9...especially if it plays well with 7 players.  My guess is that 7 players may introduce too much chaos.  Looking forward to my next play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players race their robots across the factory floor.  Robots are programmed, by dealing everyone a hand of cards, then using those cards to fill five registers.  Each register is actioned, robots are moved as directed by the card, then the factory floor kicks in - lasers fire, conveyor belts move, etc.  The interaction occurs when robots are hit, pushed, etc.  A great game if you like your chaos programmed.  Handy if you can tell left from right.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Idea:
Try to guide robot through pitfalls, lasers and moving/turning floors through the flags. While trying to shoot/distract other players robots.

Mechanism:
Put 5 direction cards for your robot secretly and all players resolve those simultaneously. Your plan may fail if something happens and if someone programmed robot fast you have less time too. Also damaged robot has less cards to choose from or even some program cards stay stuck. If robot is destroyed you return to last touched flag.

to who:
This is easy to teach and better with multiple players. Really fun time to time. I havent tried 'special scenarios' but they certainly put more play value to game.

RATING: N/A
On Long term loan to Gabe Lustik
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Each player is a robot navigating a death-trap of a factory, filled with conveyor belts, lasers, and bottomless pits.  Each turn you will "program" your robot by creating a sequence of five cards (move 2, turn left, back up, etc.) that your robot will follow, but it's a robot -- it will still blindly follow your instructions even if you mess up and turn the wrong way, or if someone bumps into you and pushes you into a square you weren't expecting to be in.  Most of the fun comes from these mistakes and the ensuing mayhem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The phrase "the more the merrier" comes to mind

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Innovative and fun, to a point. The AH version has serious quality problems... the cards are not flexible enough to shuffle without causing permanent damage. This is unfortunate because the game requires the cards to be shuffled A LOT. Gameplay is fun for a while, as it can be challenging to figure out how to program your bot to do exactly what you need to do while taking into consideration all the conveyer belts, rotating gears, etc. But once you play a few games and start to get a grasp on the visualization aspect, it really becomes more a matter of getting the cards you need in your hand. Still, a unique experience overall. Best with about 3-4 players. Get enough robots involved in the same arena and CHAOS ENSUES! And that is where the real fun is to be had.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2005 edition

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I played RoboRally once with the first english version a long time ago. It was a 5 player game and we had a blast playing RoboRally.

When we played RoboRally, the game was already out of print. Shortly after our game experience, my brother bought the german basic game which was still available at the time. The main difference between the two basic versions is that the german version supports 4 players instead of 8 players and there are no option cards. Option card are very cool to have on your robot.

To play with 8 players with the german version, you need to get the Crash & Burn expansion which can be hard to find.

Today, Avalon Hill did a reprint of the game. Original game was from Wizard of the Coast.

**Recently played 3 games with the new Avavon Hill version. One board and 4 players. We had lots of fun.

I am looking into getting the new Avalon Hill's copy of his game and getting rid of the german version. The more players the better in RoboRally. The most that I have played with so far is 6 a player game. It was on two boards. I manage to win that game too, using my mechanical arm for 2 of the 3 flags.

It is great when you shoot at the different players to cause them damage. The more players you have, the greater the headache.

I played with my mom, and she doesn't have good cordination with her left and right, the gears etc. So she can go in a pit all by herself.

8 plays since recording games played.

TRADED.

Got an Avalon Hill version of Roborally in a game trade at Granby 2010.

RATING: 2
This is the first game I'm really gonna bag on.  I played this back in the day and from then till now I still don't understand why people find this one fun.  Even giving some props to the mechanics, it still holds 0 entertainment value for me personally.  Probably deserves a 4 or 5 rating, but people's inexplicabble liking of the game forces me to make my rating out of vengeance rather than reason.  However, my spite is somewhat satiated by the fact that this game was given to me as a present and is right now in the ownership of people who actually enjoy playing it.  To each his own, I suppose.  Check out Himalaya and Space Alert for similar mechanics with gameplay that has been vastly improved upon. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I nearly wish that instead of 5 moves, you only programmed 4 at a time.  That might make things too easy for almost everyone, but sometimes when you get a hand of crappy cards you just want the turn to be over faster.  I know that everyone should get their fair share of crappy deals, so it should balance out, but it just doesn't feel like it does.  Or if there was some persisting hand, like you keep the program cards you don't use or discard, and you get dealt up to your remaining life at the next turn.  In fact... I might use that next time I play.

I think the biggest issue is an uncontrollable luck factor.  Seems like it gets to a point, the leader is set, and the game is reduced to hoping the leader gets amazingly unlucky.  It would seem that with a bit more control, you could mitigate this problem.  I also think somewhat shorter races are in order (5 flags and four boards?!  You HAVE to be kidding me)

RATING: 6
This is the most zany racing game that I've played.  I really like the programing sequence and then resolving the sequence.  There are a few issues I have with the game.  The main being is that I think it would take far two long to play with anything more than a basic track.  Unfortunately, the disadvantage of a small track is that when people get close to the goals, things will get extremely chaotic and the person that remains 'on track' can then leave the hectic area and you'll run into a runaway leader syndrome.  I don't know if I prefer this or a more traditional racing game such as Snow Tales.  This one is certainly more innovative however.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Mad rush to get cards in the right place, avoid being shot and get to the race destinations. 

Reminds me of space alert.

- So get random cards and place 5 from the 1-9 you get (depending on how damaged you may be)
- Act in sequence according to card numbers, so others may alter your path if they push you out the way (hence more people = more madness)
- The boards have conveyor belts and cogs that can move, or turn you.
- Each robots auto fires a laser at the end of each turn/round. And there can be lasers on the board, so you can get damaged (more damage, means less cards. Heavy damage means cards are locked into place)
- There are repair and upgrade spaces to heal and improve your robot!
- Don't mess up your left and right.

More people = more madness, so more fun. We played with 4 and 5. One person easily won each game (different person in each game) while 2nd to last was pretty much clumped together. Stupid conveyor belts!

RATING: 4
Though I have enjoyed it, it is polarising and there are simply better games. See 'Colt Express'
Issues:
1. Duration. Always played the 'short' races and yet they can take hours. I have no interest in playing a longer race.
2. Punishing. You are punished for failure. This is difficult to justify in a game when there is so much chaos. This would be fine if not for (above) lengthy duration.
3. Chaos. There is fun in chaos but this game just goes too far. The cards you are dealt are random, so in addition to elements on the board changing your plans but what you can do about it is also completely dependent on a random draw. This is fun at first but gets tedious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Ha, this is awesome. It rocks, it sucks, it kills. In that order. You'll laugh about your opponents, mocking them when you just botched their programmed movement, you'll cry and say bad words, when they did it to you or you mixed left with right (not that THAT happens often). And you'll get killed (well actually your robot playing piece, not your fleshy self) more often than not (either by your adversaries or yourself). The rules are simple, at least after re-reading the booklet for say, three to four times ;) (regarding the minor details, like timing sequence), but in the end everything is explained quite clearly. Now, I heavily recommend getting "Armed and Dangerous" since that will add so much more options and kill-potential (as much for yourself as for your opponents). Oh, and btw it is a lie that people with good spacial thinking have an advantage. Simply fill them up, that should even the odds. Another thing I'd hazard to recommend, rather play on a smaller area, say a single board, instead of a larger one. In that way you'll increase the contact rate quite a bit, and you can catch up to the leader, since he must cross your path several times to check all the flags. Less space + more players = more fun. So say I.

RATING: 8
This is a decent 'programming' game, and is a good bridge for non-gamers.  It does a decent job of having a balance between strategy and 'randomness'.  

A house rule I use frequently is to provide each player with 1 upgrade card for 'free'; adding an additional with each 'death'.  This tends to keep non-gamers quite engaged after a death due to the increased chance of "Revenge" or "Catching Up".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[101 plays] And looking forward to making it 1001.  I can't imagine ever tiring of this fabulously fun game.  

Roborally was fun for me right from the start.  It's a game that new players can enjoy (as long as they know left from right) even while bumbling around the board making classic beginner's mistakes and perishing.  Once you have a medium idea of what you're doing, there's enough randomness involved that you start to have a chance against better players.  But skill and experience have the edge in the long run.  

I really like the learning curve and skill-to-luck relationship here.  There's enough crazy randomness that skill disparities aren't a great barrier to entry for new players, but there's enough challenge and depth that it remains interesting as you become more skilled over time.  When I first started to be able to read the terrain, it was like a third eye opening.  

Actually, before I even could really see it myself, I remember when I began to see that the better players were seeing it.  It's like looking at a contour map:  if you're not really familiar with them, it just looks like a bunch of curvy lines.  Once the concept is explained to you, you can think through "OK, that's a hill." But if you are accustomed to making and using contour maps, you can look at one and immediately visualize the actual land.  That ability to immediately translate from the conventions of a two-dimensional map to visualizing terrain in three dimensions is akin to the skill veteran Roborally players develop in reading the board. And the more you understand the terrain, the more you can develop your ability to chart a path through it.  

The replayability here is inexhaustible.  There are so many different boards that can be combined in different ways, and near-infinite possibilities for designing your own courses on them.  (That's without even getting into the whole area of player-designed boards.)  There are also all kinds of interesting play variants.  

Roborally lends itself well to calibrating for different levels of ability.  You can set up an easy, beginner-friendly course, or a nightmarishly challenging and perilous one.  There are also a number of possible ways to handicap the game, should one wish to.  And you can design a course suitable for more or fewer players, for more or less player interaction, and for a longer or shorter game.  I'm no good at this myself, but I have seen experienced players be very accurately able to lay out a course so that the game will take a certain intended length of time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
To play games like this, I have found it's best to vet your opponents, and don't invite those who are lacking good spacial visualization, as they tend to feel frustrated after inevitably making unintended moves. Maybe, with the right attitude, they may laugh it off, but that's not the same as liking the game.

It also helps to be good at estimating degrees of success stemming from possible outcomes; anticipating the chosen path of other players' robots is vital to avoid having your robot's program interrupted. Nevertheless, you also should embrace the potential for such interaction. When it occurs, sometimes with disastrous results, you're usually faced with two options: determine whether there is sufficient time to pursue your previous goal, or go on the offensive and set back the lead player, preferably the one that pushed/redirected/exploded you off the board.

It's unfortunate some players can't see these tactical aspects beyond the haze of "too random" mechanics, because more people might decide they like it after all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have mixed feelings when it comes to Robo Rally.

The core idea and play of the game is fun but it can be quite frustrating when you draw hand after hand of cards that leave you powerless to change your circumstance, i.e. only getting turn cards.  These bad turns can bog down the game and slow it down more than it needs to be.

Given the number of revisions I am surprised to see so little documentation regarding Option Cards and from browsing the forums I can see this is a commonly grey area of much debate on the forums.  Greater clarifications on an official FAQ, errata or new edition to the rules would be appreciated as the version on Wizard’s site currently match the printing of my version.

My main issue is with Avalon Hill's 2010 printing is the boards... if you can call them that aren't really boards so much as thick card which if held at one corner flexes slightly, it may seem nit-picky but essentially fresh out of the box, my boards won't sit flush with a table and can make it slightly awkward moving bits between boards.  Normally I wouldn’t gripe about something like this but considering it is a full game with a retail MSRP of $50 USD, Wizards of the Coast need to step up their game to keep up with the solid production from companies like FFG, MayFair Games and Asmodee.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

But also bought for the kiddies because it's kind of a gateway programming game (& hubby wants to instil the virtues of computer programming at an early age). Edited to update: now have a copy of the original 80s version as well (incl two sets of robots but no box). Definitely like the flags & artwork of the new version but the old robots are kind of cool (although nothing wrong with the new robots, really...they're just not metal).

RATING: 5

Using dice, rather than cards, speeds up the game significantly.  Also, the death penalty is slightly less brutal, which is nice.

Can't beat that killer robot theme though...

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
RoboRally's fun theme is just the icing on the cake.  Underneath, it's got a perfect blend of strategy and luck.  Almost every action you perform is based on a random allotment of cards, but using what cards you're granted can be a truly exhausting exercise in strategic resource management.  The various robot upgrades are assigned randomly, but utilizing the upgrades to their full potential is a pretty intense strategy experience.  And the boards themselves are really interesting, each of them being designed with the subtle intricacy of a level in a video game.

Like most other Richard Garfield games, RoboRally's over-reliance on a complex phase structure can be bewildering, even frustrating, but it's a great game, regardless.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Played 10+ times with 3 and 5 players. I had some real concerns with this game dragging on too long (especially the first two times I played it, once at game group, once at a local game store) but the new AH ed. comes with a sand timer that but the kibosh on anal/paral. This game started out as a 7 that I thought would lose its novelty, but has since grown on me because it makes for an admittedly chaotic and very humorous game that plays well 3-8. I used to think this wouldn't work as a casual game, but I played it with two mid-casual gamers guys, and they both enjoyed it tremendously, and we were in stitches nearly the whole game. Maybe not for young kids or super casual groups, but a real blast to play. Glad I finally picked it up. // I recently taught two more buddies how to play and they LOVED it. We ended up playing 4 games in a row. I had no idea this game would be such a success.

RATING: 3
[Programming, Race] [2005 Avalon Hill reprint] Man, this is one chaotic, random game. The programming part is fine, even EASY; that's not the problem. It's even fun for a while when the board chaos is fresh, but it quickly turns frustrating as the random card deal and the narrowing options caused by damage mount. Missing turns due to shutdown or death just make the game more annoying. Throw in the long game time, the unbalanced option cards and players who are out of the running for the win long before it's over and you have a game that I'll only play again under duress.

RATING: 7.5
Rules Complexity: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
"Take That" Conflict: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

A somewhat chaotic racing game that is a blast to play with the right people and the right board setup.  It takes longer than you might think (and maybe than it should) to finish even some of the short races.  It's a great introduction to programming for younger folks, but presents a significant challenge to older ones too.

RATING: 2
I never understood the appeal of this game. It's completely random and chaotic, and not in a good way. There's basically no strategy - just have your set of cards laid out, and move your robot ( and not near anywhere where you thought you would be ). This may seem fun at first, but very quickly wears out its welcome, and the game drags on and on. It's basically an exercise in endless frustration. If that's your idea of fun, then by all means get to it. If you enjoy playing a game with actual strategy, then ignore this one like the plague. I'm glad that I sold it when I did.

RATING: 5
Finally got to play RoboRally after years and years of hearing about it and seeing about it and never getting a chance to play. I assumed from what I knew about the game that I wasn't going to like it, and it pretty much met my every expectation. Concept-wise, it's great! Programming your little robot to move around and make objectives is a cute and singular idea. But the chaos in the game makes it totally off from what I like in games. I don't even have to go into it for this comment: one bump or unexpected occurrences means your robot will go bonkers for the rest of the round, doing shit you didn't plan for. Maybe some people find this hilarious but I find it frustrating and stupid. Yeah, you could go wide out of range so that you limit the chances of your opponent hitting you, but then you're really crawling towards the objectives - and this game is kinda slow anyway. Feels very wash and repeat, even with the progression towards completing objectives. Yeah, I was actually expecting I was going to like it slightly better than what I thought it would be but it was not to be. Still, a very cute idea and so it gets points for that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Roborally is a blast.  This may not be the deepest game, and it can be rather dependant on luck, but Roborally never seizes to provide laughs.  Roborally is without any long term stategy, as tactical decisions rule the day in this offering.  Since every program is assembled from a random card draw all one can do is cross their fingers and do what they can with what they've got. Chaos is the fuel in Roborally's engine, and where as that would make most games fall apart, Roborally is held together with the strange cosmic glue.  

UPDATE:  Roborally is falling in my favor.  The game can drag on and although it can still lead to laughs, it is becoming less desired to find time on the table.

UPDATE:  With Dragon Delta becoming my preferred simultaneous action selection race game, Roborally is beginning to show it's age.  It can still generate laughs, and may well deserve a classic status, and it also is always a fun game to introduce people to, yet I have grown tired of this once often played juggernaut.

UPDATE: After a recent playing this game has been again lowered.  Roborally is a game that has alot of early appeal, but the gameplay and humor quickly wearout.  Once all players are adequate enough with programming their routes this really is nothing other than a luck fest.  The chaos and bad luck of others can be amusing, but the joke is one dimensional.  This is ultimately an adult version of snakes and ladders - but can drag on for hours.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In [b][i]RoboRally[/i][/b] you control a happy-go-lucky laser-wielding robot seeking to be the first to complete an obstacle course. The core mechanic is all players secretly and simultaneously place multiple orders that are then revealed and enacted. Your orders will then interact with your opponents' orders in unexpected ways. You'll also take damage over the game which will restrict your options and then eventually kill your bot--don't worry, you come back. The damage element adds an extra dose of chaos that I appreciate. The longer courses can outstay their welcome and so I only recommend the short- or medium-length maps.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I came in last in flags achieved - I never got one, behind a guy who had died 3 or 4 turns earlier who had only achieved 2 flags.  I really like this game.  I rate games relatively.  If I really like the game I always rate it higher than the geek average which was 7.5 so RR got a 7.85.

RATING: 4
