=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After many years of wanting to try this game and never getting the chance to. I decided to finally buy it before it was to late. What a terrific decision this turned out to be. I now own both the WOTC 2nd edition and the AH 3rd edition of the game.

This game is flat out awesome fun. The game isn't that hard to learn and after the first play or so it becomes very easy to play. Games can be played with 2-8 players, but it seems like 5-6 would be the sweet spot. It's just more fun and chaotic with robots pushing and shooting at each other all over the place. It makes the game just that much more fun.

I must admit that I do suffer from AP at times. A habit which I try to get away from with every play and I was a little afraid that this might not be a good game for me. Due to my slight AP problem, but I had no problems with it at all during game play and once you have played the game a few times. Your pace will pick up.

The components in the game are very nice. I do however like the single sided thicker boards of the WOTC 2nd edition a lot more than those of the double sided 3rd edition by AH, but they are still ok and able to be combined together. However I do like the 3rd edition flags, docking bays and player mats. They provide a very nice touch to the game.

So if you have been even the slightest bit curious about this game. Don't delay. Go out and buy it now before it's to late and goes out of print forever. This game should be in everyones collection. I highly recommend this game to everyone from Families to gamers.

Many thanks to my beautiful and loving girlfriend for finding the 2nd edition of this game and giving it to me for Christmas. Knowing that I had always wanted to try it. I love you cupcake. Your the best. :)

RATING: 3
Initial Rating: 7
I like this game much more in theory than I do in practice. Robots, lasers, mind-bending tracks to race around in a very chaotic and violent way. What's not to like?
Well, every time I've played it I have felt "Wow! this should be so much fun...but it really isn't". I think that is mostly because the programmed movement has a crippling effect on people prone to Analysis Paralysis and then the game drags on and on. Most of my games have a playtime of 3 hours, and that is with only 3 flags on a single board. Now, I'm not saying that the game is bad, I'm sure it is all kinds of fun when played with a drastically lower play time. I however have played all I can muster of this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I enjoy the "programmed movement" idea, and Robo Rally is the best implementation of that idea. Just don't make the mistake of setting up a long, difficult course, which tends to lead to a fatiguing game and/or a breakaway leader.  I recommend a modest course: two boards with two or three checkpoints. Put the checkpoints in relatively accessible locations, and place them so that there will intersecting traffic between robots who are on different "legs" of the course.  Although I love Robo Rally, it's not a safe recommendation for just anyone.  It's the type of game that requires a lot of mental energy and planning, all of which might be negated by the unpredictable choices of your opponents.  Not everyone enjoys that style of game.  Also, many players struggle with visualizing the spatial relationships and movement patterns, making the game a frustrating experience for them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really enjoy this game. Emphasis on the I. No one else does. I have far too many people declare hatred for RoboRally before the completion of game #1. People find it wearisome and spatially complex. 

I am a visual person and have no difficulty translating movement cards and conveyer belts into results on the board, but I can understand the difficulty for others. I just can't understand the hatred. I haven't given up on the game yet. With 5-6 seasoned players, I imagine this would be a joy to play.

Far too long playtime. If it played in an hour or less I would make sure it hit the table much much more often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There are things that are meant to go wrong and planning your robot in this game is definitely one of those things. It is meant that you should bump, zap and oops and to in some extent plan for that it will happen. There is definitely skill and strategy involved in the game, but it is the random things that make it fun. It takes some skill, but there is ways to avoid runaway leader problems (make the routes cross each other and don’t place the flags in too vulnerable positions). This game (with Carcassonne) opened my eyes for designer games.

I have mostly played with the newest edition and though I heard many complaints about that edition, I think it works fine and in some ways improve previous editions. I’m not entirely fond of some of the maps though, as they seem too hard or boring.

This game plays better with more players and fewer player boards. It is too bad that many of the boards aren’t that useful with playing with only one board. Why is it better with fewer boards? Well, there is more chaos and the game time is pretty short where you can usually clock in a game in little more than an hour. Why is it better with more players? Well, the interaction and chaos is the reason here. It doesn’t take much longer to play with more players and the programming is simultaneous. At most I have played with 10 players on one small board; that was fun. My recommendation is to play to 3 or 4 flags and don’t put the flags on too vulnerable spots.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
"The epic game of spinning around on the spot, while everyone else laughs." I really like it. I'm also pretty good, even while drunk, at rarely messing up. I think you need good spacial awareness (you need to imagine the bot's actions as you place your orders face down, taking into account other robots' likely moves, and conveyor belts, turntables etc. on the board). Having a mind that works in terms of event sequencing (this happens, then that, then that - I view all tasks as series of steps, so it's par for the course for me) is imperative for success; some people seem to be able to do it, while others can't. Chaotic fun, anyway.

RATING: 8
A game especially well-suited for the analytic-minded. If you're a programmer, you'll love Roborally.

However, caution must be used when designing a layout. Far, far too often, people think a long, difficult race will be fun. They're wrong. Make it short and "easy" (trust me, it'll be harder than it looks and the players will happily screw each other up every chance they get). It's far better to have a game end prematurely (you can always play again) than have it drag on and on. Playing on more than two boards is just asking for trouble.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In theory, I *love* this game. Wonderful bits, great variety/replayability, good choices, direct and indirect player interaction. But in practice, it almost *always* takes too long. Setting time limits for programming robots is a must, but also I think guidelines for how many boards per player should be established.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I like it, but everyone else in my gaming group found it confusing and irritating.  I have to admit that it is a bit long for what it is.  For example, an easy 3-point map probably takes over an hour, and longer than a Formula De race.  Since there is a lot of uncontrollable chaos (a feature on the box!), I guess you either like a bout of craziness, or you don't.

So my rating is based on having to put up with the complaints of the people who I drag into playing it!

Note that you must have at least 4 robots (players) to make things interesting, and playing more than one robot does become very confusing.

RATING: 7
pre-programmed robots with autofiring lasers in a factory that very well may kill them, what could possibly go wrong?

a great game that has a pre-program mechanic. you are pretty much assured to run into and shoot someone. the issue this game has is analysis paralysis big time. you should set up a timer that kicks on after there is only one person programming or do one for the whole programming turn. if everyone is good about it you may not have to do that but some players get really hampered by the spatial aspect of it and it can bog things down.

RATING: 3
I had a blast with this several years ago with a bunch of physicists and copious alcohol, but very recently I bought a copy and tried it out on my (increasingly long suffering) familiy.

6 of us sat down to the shortest available beginners course and it was abandoned after about 2 and a half hours, when somebody finally made it to flag 2 (out of 3).

Gripes: It's too long a game. The initiative system seems largely pointless and with so many players really slows down gameplay. It's too easy to get lousy cards. There seemed to be little player interaction except for people apologising for inadvertently shooting each other.

Possible solutions: Fix the initiative (perhaps go broustophedon, or rotate it with the dealer?). Allow card trading (people will tend to feel sorry for those behind them in the race and tell the leader to go sing - avoiding the runaway leader problem). Make shooting optional (same arguments apply).

I haven't actually tried any of these - they may save the game as a fun familiy activity, but it would be hard to damage it much IMHO.

RATING: 7
(Mai 2012, Commande internet via Francois) Un jeu intéressant, mais qui demande tout de même de bonnes capacités en visualisation spatiale. Ce n,est pas toujours évident de programmer les bons mouvements de notre robot en fonction des différents éléments perturbateurs du jeu. Il faut également être en mesure de bien visualiser ses 5 actions en avance dans sa tête avant de réaliser les actions. C'est un jeu qui amène une bonne interractivité à plusieurs et qui est divertissant, mais ça ne plaira pas à tout le monde. De plus, le facteur hasard peut faire en sorte que l'on se trouve avec des mauvaises cartes et que le robot tourne en rond ou ne fait aucun mouvement en raison de cela. C'est un jeu tout de même original et esthétique. Ce jeu frustre trop ma blonde toutefois et elle ne veut plus y jouer. C'est un jeu qui peut plaire toutefois aux amateurs de jeux vidéo!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating after one play. I like the flexibility provided by the multiple boards, and to my knowledge, it has pretty unique mechanics. However, I found myself fighting with the mechanics more than actually playing the game. I was forever picking the wrong turn card because I forgot which way the conveyor would spin me. Although I suspect this would change with more plays, it then seems to me that there would be an obvious optimal path to take, and if you couldn't take it, it would be purely luck of the draw. The pushing rules make it so that when there IS player interaction, it happens purely by chance, and mostly ends up hurting both players. Shooting rules are similar; you sometimes accidentally shoot people, but can't really try to go for the kill. Finally, there are a multitude of upgrade cards but only a couple will ever make it into play. That is sad, because they would give it a lot more variety. A game like this would benefit from starting player powers, but if not, it would at least be better if more of these upgrades came into play. Monsters Menace America, King of Tokyo, etc. handle mutation/modification cards a lot better. Nevertheless, I would be willing to play this one again. Perhaps some of my concerns were specific to the scenario.

RATING: 9.25
This is one of my absolute all-time favorite games.  It is just the perfect marriage of theme, planning, and chaotic mayhem.  Don't make the mistake of using more than 2 boards at once!  You need to keep the players all very close together to maximize accidents.  Because there is nothing funnier than someone getting pushed into a hole or onto an inescapable conveyor belt when they didn't expect it, and watching the death play out slowly via their subsequent commands.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Initial Impression: 7] I thought this would be a fairly dry exercise in programmed movement, but it turns out to be far more fun than I would have thought. I have to project myself "into" the board in order to track the effects of gears, conveyor belts, etc., but it gets the job done. Miscalculate, or have someone with a higher priority push you before your movement, and you'll find your bot wildly off course. Recovering from such mishaps and locked actions takes a special kind of fluidity and vision, including an ability to adapt to the cards at hand. Spatial thinkers will love it, and it will make others cringe. The chaos comes from the interactions between players as they try to reach the same goals simultaneously, but predicting and reacting to others adds the element of uncertainty that makes the game shine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
RoboRally, where basic robotic programming meets hand management, chaotic mazes, and the sand-timer for some interactive robot madness.

It's unfortunate that no one has republished all the increasingly pricy expansion boards for this, and it's easy to lust over the old Wizards of the Coast versions and their pewter robots, but the basics are captured and delivered, even in the Hasbro/A-H reprint that I own.

Chaos, and bad things happening to you, have rarely been so hilarious.  A runaway leader may cruise to victory, but still the Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Factory floor of RoboRally is a hoot.

Caveat: if you do not find spacial-thinking/planning your cup of tea, and/or are not a computer progammer, this may not be the game for you.

But I have loved this game since playing my friends copies of the Wizards of the Coast edition(s), and I think this is one of those games all gamers should just have: for me this is an essential.  Great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Reminiscent of the computer games Robot War and Robo Sport, as well as the Star Fleet Battles board games. It is a smart game, requiring precision forethought, as well as some luck. This is a game that a computer programmer would absolutely LOVE.

The object of the game is to race your robot across the various random boards to touch a given number of flags (number up to the players) and then return to the starting flag to win.

You get nine cards in which to program five moves for your robot in your five registers. The cards are a random mix of move forward, backward, left/right turns, and U-turns. Everyone locks in their five moves, and then all moves are executed simultaneously, although the timing on the cards tell you what moves take precedence, as one robot could push another robot before that robot has a chance to move. If a robot is in the LOS of another, then it takes a point of damage. Robots can take up to 10 pts before being destroyed, and players start with 4 lives. However, the more damage a robot has, the fewer cards he receives for the next round! On the 5th hit, the last register is "locked", and hence the robot will be forced to execute the last move card programmed there. It is possible to reset the damage/memory by shutting down, but this means you're a sitting duck for a turn. You can also repair damage if you arrive at a "wrench/repair/archive" point.

The boards represent treacherous factory floors, where there are conveyor belts, turntables, pits, and other contraptions designed to mess up your movement (by moving/turning you unwillingly in-between your registered moves), or at worst, kill you. One false move, and you could fall into a pit, losing a life, and setting you back to your last "archive" point. This is a way-point you set on the board, so you don't have to start all over again at the start flag.

You need a math degree in vector analysis to do well in this game (well, sort of). Given your cards and looking at the board, it is a deterministic exercise in optimally programming your robot to make the most progress towards a flag, given the cards you are dealt. However, there is substantial interaction among the players as your plans may be severely disrupted by another player's faster move. So, your perfect path could lead you into a pit (like what happened to me several times in the first game). Also, there are "option" cards which give the robots additional offensive/defensive/movement capabilities.

It's chaotically fast play, with some potential downtime in programming the cards by some AP players, but always results in funny and generally frustrating outcomes. The game length can be adjusted to the players' tastes. Since it is a race, players will bunch up on another during the first several turns (and around flags), but a good/lucky player will be able to break-away and coast to victory (literally, on the conveyor belts). There is no catch-up mechanism, but hey, that's life (and robots).

RATING: 5
The archetypal programmed movement game. It's a good humoured, if highly chaotic experience with far too little control for this to qualify as a strategy game. Don't set up too large a board as the game can drag on, especially with more players. Great miniatures.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
1st played 01/02/08. Taught in ~10min. Played w/ 4 & took 2 hrs w/ the start board, however we didn't discard unused cards each round (slowed down). The object is to make it to 3 checkpoints (in order) before others do. Players pick 5 cards for a phase hidden, from their hands (start w/ 9), in a specified sequence. Cards are move 1-3, move 1 backwards, turn left/right, or u-turn. Spaces on the board: spin left/right, laser 1pt damage (dam), move 1x/2x on track, repair 1 pt dam (if you end the round there) & walls (block view/movement). Everyone plays a card & then evaluate the board at the end of each phase (including robot shots in direction faced at others). You have 9 dam pts before you die & have 3 lives. You also die if you run off the map. If you end a phase at a checkpoint you can clone yourself there (death restart space). Each dam received, one less card drawn. After a few dam pts, late phase cards are locked & carry to next round. Bots may %u201Cpower down%u201D to repair all dam; however are sitting ducks that round (don%u2019t move). Special improvement cards can be received when bots are on certain spaces at the end of a round. I'd recommend it if you know someone who has it, however I wouldn't consider purchase.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
6/13.

Yes - that means that 2 hrs was because I was slow... not my kids. My 6-yr old even impressed me with his ability to calculate where his robot was going to end up at the end of the turn through a conveyor belt and gear! Overall was a blast to play and I look forward to bringing this out a whole lot more with my kids.

RATING: 8
More fun than I had expected.  You're trying to get your robot through the course before everyone else, but not only are they trying to melt you into a puddle with lasers, the course is trying to smash you flat.  You get a hand of cards each turn and then play five of them to set up your sequence of moves.  Hilarity ensues when a mistake is made or something unexpected happens, resulting in the robot doing exactly what you had ordered, in the wrong place.

RATING: 1
I don't overly mind bad or mindless games; though I feel this is one of the worst games I've ever played. I suppose children would love this game due to the silliness factor. However the game mechanics are so random that I feel you may as well just submit your moves at random and see what happens. Game play takes forever and all you do is move around in a semi random direction (cards direct movement, there's alot of turn cards) hoping that you get to the flags and not in the pits. I will never suggest this game to anyone (child or adult) and will walk out of a games day if the game is brought out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not awful, not great. The player who gets out in front usually comes off the best, but as soon as players start taking damage the game rapidly descends into frustrating chaos. 
Also, with more than 3 players, games can drag somewhat. Even 'quick' 1 board games with 3 checkpoints have been known to drag on for 3-4 hours with 7 or 8 players.
Have played this a few times where I've had a clean run to the finish in 1st place and then sat and waited 1-2 hours until the 2nd place comes in to the finish. Just lucky card draws and not being interrupted by any other bots, rather than skillful play on my part. This is obviously a problem with the game. 
A good house rule would appear to be to give everyone 2 upgrade cards at the start. None makes for a boring game, while a single card per person often leads to one player having a clear advantage. The chances of getting 2 great cards are slimmer, so this seems to be a good medium. It also lends each player more of a unique 'character' to their bot.

Fun, but be very careful not to get too ambitious with your board layouts. 2 boards with 6 players, 3-4 checkpoints and 2 upgrades to start will be a fun (but still potentially unbalanced) 150-180 minute game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2011-06-12

Initial Rating: 4.5 

Didn´t like it very much. It has a long play time and I find the luck factor to be annoyingly high. I don´t think I will play this again soon.

Edit 2011-12-27

After much avoiding and deliberation, my friends managed to convince me to play this again and I’m very glad :D. This time I had a lot of fun.

I enjoy the simultaneous programmed movement mechanic and the game offers lots of laughs but BEWARE, don´t make the same mistake I did, play a small scenario with lots of opportunities to interact, otherwise you will begin to hate the downtime and the sameness of the game.

This is not a game for everyone, play before buy

New rating: 6.5

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is fun even if you kill yourself.  Program your best and let the chaos begin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Race your robot to get to the flags in the correct order. Play five movement/turn cards at a time in a "program" for the turn. All programs executed simultaneously. Robots push and shoot each other so your program may be interrupted.

Good interaction.  I've introduced over 20 people to this game and played with over 50, and I assure you every single one has at least found it ok, and of course most enjoyed it.  Make sure: (1) *Never* play on more than 2 boards  (2) Always have some trail crossing between targets.  Also, a "negative feedback scavanger hunt" house rule rebalances the leader for those who like to put the brakes on any early advantage.   In any case, best played with Armed and Dangerous. And personally there's three Options which we remove: Robocopter, Fire Control, Buzz Bomb.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
German Version

RATING: 10
WotC '94, 1st ed.  Arrrgh!  What a delightfully frustrating game this is, especially for those of us who are spatially impaired.  The luck in the draw of the programming (movement) cards is balanced by the skillful use in making the most out of them.  I appreciate the fact that you can customize the game length and complexity to facilitate any level of play.  We play a lot of 2-player games using 1 board, 4 flag counters and 3 lives along w/ the deal-2-keep-1 option card variant at the beginning of the game.  Very happy to finally have this in our collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Battle Bots comes to board gaming in this extremely fun adaptation. Chaos erupts into laughter as players sometimes confuse their own perspective of what's left and right with the one of the robot, all while near-simultaneous play and challenging board layouts offer exciting perils for your machine. It doesn't have enough of a combat mechanic for me, but I still love playing it -- and I have to give an extra bonus point for any game that comes up with a way to force slow players into catching up!

MEGA PLUS: thirty seconds left for the last player to choose their moves
BIG PLUS: huge entertainment factor, mental challenge
MINUS: one mistake can be costly, really more about planning
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
One of the games that got me into board gaming. Enjoyment will depend on a few things: 1)How well can you visualize the robots movement.Because those that can't picture where the robot will go tend to get frustrated. 2) How well the boards are set up. I'd play with 2 boards and 3 flags. Put the flags in reachable locations that are no more than two rounds from each other assuming a normal hand of cards. Those two things should keep games to an hour or so. Good solid game.

MG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game where you program your moves five turns at a time and hope that your programs pan out as you anticipated. With the conveyor belts, gears, lasers, and other robots bumping and shooting you - finishing five moves where you had planned to finish is more challenging than it sounds.

GREAT game with the right crowd. Lots of laughs bumping into each other and shooting each other up - sometimes on purpose, but often inadvertently. The game can feel out of your control at times and those who are overly frustrated by having their plans foiled may find this more maddening than fun. The variable maps and card draws can make the quality of the game sessions with this highly variable, but also ensures variety. It's a fun, solid design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A perfect party game! The more players the better! If you do not pick a too large map and lay out the checkpoints in an interesting way, you even end up with a reasonably long game...

Go fetch it, right now!

RATING: 3
Ugh!!   This is one of the games I really have a negative reaction when people suggest it.  Really don't like the randomness, and random chaos, of having to predict five moves in advance. Would prefer to have a version where you have to plot just one move at a time; i.e., can you imagine Speed Circuit or Formula De where you would have to post five turns in advance?

RATING: 6.5
Fun, Fun, Fun that's all this game is.  For me, it doesn't matter if your getting the shaft it's still fun.  The game greatly attends to my problem solving mind and you get a huge sense of satisfaction when your plans unfold the way you wanted them to.

However, we wary of a runaway leader

Update: This is probobly the most controversial game I own in that there almost always is a player or two who does not have a good time and then there are several who have a blast.  On our last play I had someone vow they would never play again.  As always, someone always dominates at the end and the race is never close.  I personally rate this an 8.5 regardless if a win or lose, but because so many people can get really frustrated with this game I have to take it down a point.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This was the most popular game with my non-gamer friends during the 90's. The programming mechanism works great and it's always big fun when somebody prefers eliminating other players to winning the game. The secret to enjoyable games is the right construction of the courses. Players have to criss-cross others on the way back, the number of boards should be tailored to the number of players. Early on, we made the mistake to choose as many boards as possible and lay them in a row. The result were lacklustre games of runaway winners/losers.

RATING: 4
The visual challenge of this to a legally blind player like me is pretty close to a killer. I kept running into nigh-invisible walls. As with any programmed-movement game, it can be fun or frustrating depending on how thwarted you get and how long the game takes. A quick, say, Wings of War duel is fun; a long circling exercise in which no one can kill off the other isn't. Same with RoboRally. Add the general "challenges" of programmed movement to automatic laser firing, smaller hands of movement cards, and (with enough damage) some or all "frozen" maneuver cards, and my eyes start glazing over.

RATING: 8
I'm a little less than thrilled at the actual quality of the components for the recent printing (2009?).  

The "painted robots" look junky and badly done.  The stickers for the flag are a little...weird.  (Going to have to dig out a hobby knife to cut it so I can get one to go on the base without looking weird.

That being said, the actual gameplay is quite fun and is a nice change of pace from brainburners.  Sure, there's some thinking involved in movements and planning right, but the general lightness of the game keeps me from feeling too upset when I screw up.

Not everything needs victory points.  Sometimes it's just nice to have a game with robots with fricken lazers attached to their head.

RATING: 8
Race to the checkpoint game with quirky robots. Game designed from Battle bots concept. Moderately challenging, entertaining game but [b]requires a good grasp of spacial abilities and planning. [/b]

I've seen a hand full of players who can't grasp the left from their right - not as easy as you think! Lack of mobility and randomization of the cards adds to [b]frustration[/b]. Getting several bad hands is very discouraging.

Overall, feels like progress is pretty slow, but [b]fun with chaos of 5+ players[/b].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Game length is unpredictable, but having the freedom to create your own courses is great.

RATING: 6
Really enjoyed my first game of this (short as it was). The weight of the game seems heavier due to the computational aspect of it. The rules are actually pretty simple. The game is chaotic and actually planning out attacks on your fellow players is difficult. This makes it all the more enjoyable IMO. Given some moderately experienced players this game shouldn't take too long, however, some people just don't have the knack and it'll take them an age each round.
UPDATE: Programmed play is picked up by Space Alert, a country mile ahead of this slightly clunky game. I enjoy it but it takes too long comparatively. Dropped from 8 to 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of my all time favourites.
I use some houserules to make it a better game (imho)
-If you die, just start at last checkpoint with 2 damage. -As a result we don't use powerdowns generally.
-You can't get out of the game.
-You have 1 minute after the first player puts down his cards.
-I only use the option cards sometimes because I think the game is chaotic enough without these cards.

-Use 2 boards at once max. Bigger playing fields doesn't mean more joy. Better go criss cross over a small area to get more player interaction.

Plays very well as a 2 player game.
Higher player counts (6+) only with experienced players.

RATING: 7
Fun game about a race of robots in a futuristic factory. Has a good mix of planning and chaos.Each turn you lay cards to plan the movement of your little robot. Sometimes it can be pretty difficult to actually end up where you wanted to. A lot of the time something goes wrong because your planning wasn't that perfect (ooops you forgot about the conveyor belt? Well bad luck you get shot by a laser...) or because another robot pushes you around.
The remake has thrown out all rules that could potentially slow down the game - which i think overall is a good thing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game has received more playtime than it probably deserves on account of the fact that it plays up to 8. Essentially this game works as a race, where people are often unable to do what they want (because movement is controlled by cards) and where no one gets to where they want to be because other players' turns affect what can be done.

Playing this game with 8 is a nightmare; I don't think I've ever gotten through an 8-player game of this without calling it at some point.

One key problem is that players with poor spatial awareness and sequential reasoning are going to get mauled all the time by this game and there's nothing that can be done about it. I personally stop having fun when 3 people are racing well against each other and one person is miserable and is just turning around in circles because their brain just can't visualize what's going on well enough. In addition because this game punishes taking a long time to take a turn (which is a good thing because otherwise turns would get very, very long) the least adept ends up getting wrecked from without and within the most.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I like robo rally a lot, mostly cause of the flavor and that I painted my own figs, giving me a chance to showoff.  The game BEGS to be customized in terms of how to lay out the board, how to assign upgrade stuff, and how to determine win conditions.  That, too me, makes this game worth it.  The rules given are simple (adding complexity is as simple as buying the expansions) and therefore give us the chance to make the game as we see fit.  When we played just the original game, straight rules, unfortunatly, once someone starts winning, it's hard to stop'em, but the game gives SO much room to create your own board, rules, upgrades, any "problem" in the game is IMO ultimately solvable, and maybe a game in and of itself.
oh, and ya gotta get the expasions...

RATING: 6
Got this as a gift from the board game exchange on reddit. My Secret santa thought my son would love it and he was right. The trick is not not over-analyze your movement options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really like the simultaneous action selection mechanic, and I think this game uses it nicely. And I don't have to deal with the wheedling you get in Diplomacy. This game really is at its best with a larger number of players. With 2, it is a race where the better cards will likely win, and there is likely to be very little interaction. The true fun of this game lies in robots crossing one another's paths.

Oh, a timer is a must. The rules say that after all but one player is finished, the final player gets 30 more seconds to put down his cards. Okay, fine, but if you have two really slow players, it's still way too slow. Better to use an electronic time programmed for a minute or so. Maybe 90 seconds for a more casual group. Really needed to keep the game moving.

I only wish the cards shuffled themselves each round.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game of [racing|programming|damage control]. I rediscovered this with the 2005 AH edition, having previously felt somewhat lackluster about it -- probably due to complicated courses and/or longwinded games. The sample setups included in the AH edition probably helps bringing about a more balanced game.

A good thing about RR recently pointed out to me is that even if your behind or in your own corner of the board, you still have a small optimisation problem to solve each turn programming your moves. This keeps each player occupied at all times.

I think playing with an at start option shakes things up a little, and adds to the fun.

Kudos to AH for re-releasing this!

(Update: Played the Wizards of the Coast version this weekend -- it does suffer from the "virtual" robots as well as from the lack of a timer & player mats. Still good fun, though. Give it a 7.)

RATING: 7
This was love at first play! About 10 minutes into my first game, I looked over at my wife and said "I must have this game". Cards are "programmed" into your robot to try and guide them to tag the flags in order. The problem is that the other robots and the environment (a dangerous factory filled with all kinds of damaging and course-altering elements) will often disrupt or at least influence how your programming will turn out. This game has appeal for all ages and is extremely well-designed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
RoboRally is a mixed bag. I like the game if it's played as quickly as possible, with everyone likely to make serious mistakes on each turn. But if two players attempt to slow down play and cover all their bases the gameplay drags and the results become much less chaotic (and thus, much less enjoyable). Also, the game is seriously unbalanced in favor of those with a more acute sense of spatial orientation. The game is better with more players, and I'd say that with any less than five you should probably play something else. Still, the variety of maps and the quick, chaotic gameplay certainly make RoboRally fun.

RATING: 6
B-Top
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Roborally is an incredibly chaotic game in which players must program robots to race through the most deadliest course ever.

Each player simultaneously programs five orders for its robot in secret, and then they are resolved. As orders are resolved, robots may push each other, not to mention there are all sorts of obstacles scattered throughout the board, such as conveyor belts, which will move robots around too. And here is where Roborally's fun resides: you must try to do your best with the order's you've been dealt, while keeping in mind both the board and other players.

The game is very chaotic and, at times, very luck driven, but it has an undeniable charm and, most of all, it's unique. While the meat of the game it's at the programming phase, it's when you are resolving orders where the fun is: seeing how robots race to victory or, on the other hand, rush relentlessly to their doom, is really fun.

The game is specially recommended for those who like thematic games and have tried to program a robot at some point in their lives. If you've ever goofed around with a Lego Mindstorm, you'll be surprised how well Roborrally captures the theme, while simultaneously adding layers of hilarity.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:4~6
:thumbsdown:2

[i]To have more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]

RATING: 8
I've only played this f2f a couple times, but found it quite enjoyable.  Riotous fun meets analytical thinking.  The only drawback I see is getting a large enough group of players together to keep it interesting.  I generally get my fix on GTO.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
RoboRally has been described as a party game for geeks and I wholehearted agree with this statement. It is a fun game with lots of interaction and thoughtful planning. In RoboRally, you will try to be the first to move your robot across a number of checkpoints in a rather bizarre factory. During the race, you will have to use the conveyer belts to your advantage and avoid the negative effects of crushers, lasers and other robots. RoboRally is a great planning game, although you'll never be able to predict with certainty where your robot will end. Certainly avoid falling in pits! Instead, push another robot in a pit or even off the board ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An excellent and fun game where players use cards with instructions to "program" their robot tokens to move around the board, playing a "capture the flag" game with added lasers, crushing parts, moving conveyers, and death pits. The ability to customize the board to the group's challenge level and desired play time is nice, with suggested board layouts and extra mechanics included in the rulebook. The option cards allow for special bonus powers as well, changing up gameplay if the default mode isn't exciting enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played with: Sebas de Jongh

RATING: N/A
Your task is to move one of the stupid little robots out on the factory floor through a series of checkpoints scattered throughout the factory. The wrinkle, however, is that the factory floor is filled with all kinds of inconvenient (if not down-right deadly) obstacles located in various locations: conveyor belts, crushers, flame-throwers, pushers, teleporters, oil slicks, pits, et cetera. But the real fun comes when the robots cross each other's path, and suddenly your perfect route is something less than that...

Crash and Burn expansion included in Avalon Hill Edition

RATING: 9
This is a great game for my engineering and computer science friends to get together and play.  The game can become a blow out if one robot manages to get separated from the pack.  To overcome this, our group adds a dummy robot that always spawns at the next flag that the leader is required to touch.  The control of this robot rotates around the table, this can slow the game down more but it keeps the leader closer to the rest of the pack and forces more mayhem.

RATING: 7
Basically, I scored this game high because I enjoy a diversity of game mechanics.  This game's mechanism intrigues me in planning five steps ahead and the potential for being totally knocked off kilter by what others do in their preplanned moves.  Be sure to play this game with an egg timer that forces people to make decisions with their programming cards quickly or this game will likely drag.  While it plays 8 and comes with numerous boards, I would advocate for playing on 1-2 boards and 3-5 players to keep the game relatively short (And DON'T START with the complex looking boards!..:-) )

RATING: 8
Jeder erhält eine Kartenhand von 0-9 Karten (abhängig seiner Beschädigung) und muss mit diesen die nächsten 5 Züge seines Roboters auf dem Spielplan programmieren. Während den Zügen schießen die Roboter gegenseitig aufeinander, das Brett befördert via Förderbänder die Roboter irgendwohin und geschubbst, getreten und gestoßen wird auch noch. Wer als erstes diesem Wirrwar entkommt, hat leichteres Spiel, da er sich nur noch mit dem Board konfrontieren muss, aber den Konkurrenzknäul hinter sich lassen kann.

RATING: 5
I have had a lot of fun with RoboRally and horrible experiences with RoboRally.  Some games I have played are chaotic fun, where everyone has a great time.  Others have dragged on way over an hour where you a bored to tears.  It is very much a function of how you setup your maps and keeping them small.  

Also, it is not a bad idea to deal out a special ability at the start.  

I must admit the bad outweighs the good.  It can be fun but when offered, I almost always ask to do something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2

Dragon Delta or Wings of War fill this programmed-chaos niche for me.  They are simpler, faster and more fun.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Light and chaotic, this seems like it should be a fun game, but a major flaw kills it for me (severe runaway leader problem). One player randomly is less screwed up by others at the start, and once ahead they get uninterrupted movement, while everyone else is hindered by being amongst others in the pack.

So after a quarter of the game time, you know how things are going to turn out, its boring playing as the leader because you just run for the goals without much interaction, its frustrating playing as anyone else because nothing they can do can effect the outcome.

Its a shame because I like the mechanics of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Roborally is one of those bipolar Love/Hate games. Either you enjoy the chaotic/unpredictable gameplay that can ruin your best laid plans or you get frustrated and every game is a infuriating test of your patience. Fortunately I include myself in the former group and think that Roborally is a great way to spend a few hours with some friends or family. The key (IMO) to appreciating the game is to ignore the board set-up in the rules and play 1 board per player (up to 4 boards max) and place flags so that paths have to cross. Armed and Dangerous adds more death and destrucution (adding length), while the other expansions give more board options to deal with (can add length as well but some also speed play depending). 

I think the point at which you really start enjoying the game is at what I call, the "Aha!" moment. This is where the programming becomes second nature to you. The more you play, the more familiar with the boards and the way that they will interact with your robots. Up until the point where all of that is 2nd nature, the game seems really luck driven. The reality couldn't be farther from the truth however. Once you can program your robot and KNOW where it will end up and which direction it will be facing, you can program your robot to do almost exactly what you want it to do. I say almost as the other players certainly will have a say in it at some point. But good programming skills can keep you out of 80% of harm's way. At some point you realize you are no longer confused or surprised when you move your robot, and it's that point where you go...Aha! Get a group that are all skilled in programming and you'll be amazed at some of the things that happen.

Of course even the best laid programs go awry, but the difference is not through your ineptitude, but through the better program of an opponent.

My group loves this game. We never play with more than 3 boards or 4 flags and the games take about 2-3 hours. Oh and btw....it's a SIN to play with unpainted Robots!

...[b] Abstract [/b]...__________[]...[b]Themed [/b].....
.........[b] Luck [/b]..._______[]___...[b] Skill [/b]...........
......[b] Simple [/b]...___[]_______...[b] Complex [/b]...
..[b] Strategic [/b]...________[]__...[b] Tactical [/b]....
....[b] Friendly [/b]...______[]____...[b] Cutthroat [/b]..
.......[b] Fiddly [/b]..._______[]___...[b] Elegant [/b].....

RATING: 9.5
Incredibly fun game.  The most often heard complaint is that it takes too long to play but many of the people I have talked to that complain this also say they are playing with 6+ flags on as many boards.  Keeping the number of flags and, more so, boards reasonable makes the game faster and helps keep one player from gaining an early, unassailable lead.

Almost everyone I have ever introduced this game to absolutely loves it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I usually don't cackle uncontrollably at the misfortune of others, but I sure do when playing RoboRally. Something about the way someone's carefully laid plans fall apart brings out the evil in me.

To be sure, the game isn't perfect - the game can go way too long for one thing - but it is something of a classic. What I find wildly original isn't so much the programmable movement as it is the use of the timer to force people to play quickly and send their robot out without fully calculating the consequences of their plans.

It's amazing to me that the same genius who made this game also made the abomination known as King of Tokyo...

RATING: 3
While I can see the apeal in a Rube Goldberg sort of way there's far too much chaos for me. The damage mechanic is particularly punitive and eventually forces you to actually skip your turn (power down). If you get an early lead you can usually keep clear of most of the trouble and cruise to a victory. This is painful for the players who are tangled up with each other constantly getting pushed off of their intended paths and exchanging lasers. The upside of this runaway leader problem is that the game actually ends otherwise it's just stuck in an infinite DO-loop.

RATING: 2
What a stinker of a game! I am generally tolerant of most games, but can't stand this one and will likely never play it again after only 2 plays. Why? Too much thought required for tense planning of moves, only to have it really not matter at all, since one bump from an opponent sets you off on a random course which most likely ends in doom. Add to this the huge weak-player syndrome, which ensures that newbies like me will never play again after getting smoked by veterans (i.e. anyone whose played it more than once); way too much chaos for way too long of a game; plus player elimination. Boo! My wife can't stand this one either :(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played 9 times.
Last play was Sept 23, 2007.

This is a fun game.  It is a little random on how things go, but it is full of suprising moments.  More players is better.  This game takes a little practice, but even when you know what you are doing you can still get messup pretty good.

Last night we played a team game of pure carnage... no flags.  The teams were randomly chosen and ended up being a little unbalanced (first turn my partner went into a pit with out any help from anyone else.)  The game also took a long time and my partner and I ended up with only 1 life point left while the only one player on the other team had lost even one life point, by the time my partner had to leave, so the last turn we both programed our robots to commit suicide by jumping into pits.  But it was fun, we just learned a few thing to make next time play better.  Like either handicaping one team (less life points?) or starting with fewer life points to begin with to make the game quicker.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
This one is hard to rate. The interaction during the game is as fun an experience as I have had. The table talk, pushing your opponents off the board, shooting powered down bots with your "ass" laser, and making sound effects are an awesome way to spend the evening. However, the game play is slightly dull. Unless everyone is piled up screwing each other's programing, the only goal is to find the quickest route using your 5 cards - BORING. It is really the only game I played where winning is the boring part. So, I don't love the mechanics, the experience is boring, but the interaction is awesome.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a game I fell into by accident. The theme did not appeal to me; I hated the idea of "programmed moves" (there's history there, but I won't go into it); the quality of components is far inferior to what you'd expect to find in a European game - Avalon Hill's component quality is pretty shocking, to my mind. 
I had long resisted the temptation to play RoboRally, yet this is one of the best games I've played for a balance of interaction, personal tactics and speed. It's phenomenally easy to teach and play, but fiendish in its complexity - by which I mean, anyone can use their cards to move, but it takes skill and planning to minimise card use, and make your available hand fit the moves you want to make. Yes, there's the luck of the draw, but it heightens rather than detracts from the planning. A successful move gives you a rush, and the sand timer piles on the pressure.

I am always willing to be converted, and this game has won me over. A solid 9, right from first play. Genius (with the caveat that, with a full complement of 8 players, this is probably chaotic to the point of being unplayable).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast and chaotic racing/programming game where your piece's movement over the hazardous-filled board is laid down five steps in advance under time pressure. The best laid down plans are naturally foiled as one's mistakes and the opponents' movements interfere with the program that still must be performed in spite of the new situation, with almost certain catastrophe and hilarity in consequence. Medium-high degree of direct player interaction and medium session times of about 90 minutes for five players.

RATING: 8
This is a wonderful casual game which I thoroughly enjoy playing.  The humor and silliness of the game make it very enjoyable without requiring too much heavy thinking, and the constant player interaction makes for some hilarious encounters.  It's not without its flaws as the board often gets crowded with more players and it suffers from player elimination, but I'm more than willing to look past those for some extremely entertaining gameplay.  It's a great game to introduce to non-gamers and a wonderful break from more serious games.  Everyone I know enjoys this game, although it's been quite a while since this one hit the table.

RATING: 6.5
I want to like this game more. It would seem to be right up my alley. And when I start playing it, I'm always saying to myself how much fun it is. BUT, then the crunch for Flag 1 happens, it takes 45 minutes just to clear it, and then the players who get passed the flag first sail away into the sunset with everyone else in their rear view mirrors while they zoom away unhindered. In the two games I've played, the game takes a little bit too long, and the leaders run away from everyone else leaving the other players with little to no chance to catch up. For theme and mechanics, I give this a 10. For length and runaway leader problem, I give it a 5.

RATING: 10
RoboRally, despite being an American game, was the game that really turned me on to
                                                   Designer/German games. Despite being a long, and to many people, complicated
                                                   game, I played a lot of this, and was fortunate enough to get all the expansions before
                                                   they, and the main game, went out of print in the US. I highly recommend this game,
                                                   especially to those with a technical bent. I haven't played it much recently (4 times in
                                                   the past 2 years), but I expect to occasionally play it for many years to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pick sequential orders to first move your robot to the finish line.

Plays: A couple.
Type: Thematic race game – a theme-driven game where you race to be the first across the finish line.
Complexity: Medium.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: Depends on the race and the number of players.
Player interaction: Racing. Conflict. 
Randomness: High - card draw.

Replayability: Low. This is very much an "in the mood" game. Once in a while is enough.
Fun: This is designed to be fun above all. The decision making under time pressure is fun. The spatial thinking is fun. Particilarly when you get it wrong and your poor robot runs into a laser. Or a pit, or off the board. Or when some other robot pushes yours onto a conveyor belt, completely screwing up your program for the rest of the turn, leaving you far, far from where you wanted to go. No other game is as much fun when things go wrong. Sometimes it's even fun when things go right! Strangely though, this is most fun when you fail spectacularly.
Memorability: Pretty high, the hapless robots and their failures are quite inspiring.

Thematic integration: Theme rules over mechanisms here.
Components: Good.

Who will like this: Strategy gamers that enjoy the theme and want a laugh.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ah, Robo Rally. The game that started it all for me. My first game was 8 players, 7 of them new, and started at 1 in the morning. Hysterical, chaotic bliss. This is actually a game I think is better the worse you are at it- once you master getting around in the game it devolves a bit into a fairly straight-forward rally. However, clever flag placement or house rules can fix that (Brad and I play football-style every now and then, four robots on a side, one dedicated flag-tagger and the rest running interference). I still love it though, and will gladly play it in whatever form whenever I can.

RATING: 10
Love it!

RATING: 6
Picked up in a mathtrade... 

Tried for the first time tonight with my son - a hysterical, laser blasting, shoving pushing, exploding, moving, turning racing time. One of the most fun game sessions I've had in a while, and I played a bunch of games earlier in the day preceding this one.

Several unrecorded plays of this. My problem, I think, is that I just don't care for these games where I program my moves, and then spend the second half of every round sitting there watching the outcome passively without any control.

That, combined with the ridiculous game-length makes this a game that hasn't seen the table in quite a while. Not even the kids enjoy it.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It's robots!  Moving across a booby-trapped map!  There are lasers and drills and battering rams, oh my!  What could go wrong?

Well . . . quite a bit, actually.  For my money, RoboRally does so very many things right - fantastic art, great design, lots of variety and replay value - but then stumbles into a major, if not exactly fatal, flaw.  

One of my most important metrics in evaluating a non-cooperative game - and I recognize many others may simply not feel this way - is how well it engages the player(s) who is losing the worst.  Does the last place player feel the compulsion to press on, grasping at the slim chance of victory, or out of sheer enjoyment?  Or does s/he just feel like participation is a waste of time?

RoboRally falters badly on this score.  Simply put, if you get off to a bad start in this game (which can happen due to your own incompetence, opponent machinations, or random chance), you might as well pack it up.  I've never played a game that is more punishing for its lagging players, with the possible exception of Diplomacy.  Moreover, because you simply respawn upon dying, you can never simply die with dignity (or hilarity).

When a game of RoboRally is going well, it can be tremendous fun - it is intense without being tense, competitive without being hostile.  But when it goes badly, which happens all too often, there is too broad a "spread" between the front of the line and the back of the pack to make it enjoyable.  That flaw bars RoboRally from the ranks of the regular favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
'Program' your robots moves in advance and then reveal and carry out those moves as you race to clear the checkpoints and get to the finish amongst all the factory floor obstacles including conveyor belts, pits and lasers!

The predetermined movement is a genius idea, and makes for a fair but often accidentally violent game. Good fun, but plays best with 4+ players (which sadly stretches the game on for TOO long).

Quite a bit of deck strain with 5+ players- almost every card must be used per draw- without sleeves my cards have quickly worn out.

Also shame AH didn't re-make the expansions...

Lastly I've found as my games group changes so does like for this game- certain players find RoboRally boring and frustrating to various degrees which naturally spoils my experience as well.

This game can drag out exponentially depending upon course size/difficulty, and although its fun for an hour its sucks when you are still not half way through after 3 hours!

The timer is also a double-edged knife- sure it cuts out  AP players dragging on the game for even longer, but they will also despise the game with a vengeance! I have a gamer who is AP prone but also doesn't like pressure mechanics in games- he had barely decided on two cards by the time the timer had ran him out every turn and he hated it to the point of sapping the fun for everyone.

Completely inferior to the more recent edition.

Progressive Rating: 10-9-7-9-8-6.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
RoboRally is a fine game, and it definitely has some really good qualities.  I like the simultaneous move planning, and I like that it can play with a wide range of players.  The upgrade cards are a good touch, though I wish they were easier to get, and the ability to customize maps is always a plus.

But I just don't find myself enjoying this game as much as I think I should.  Perhaps its that your control over movement is on such a fine level that the progress comes really slowly.  Or perhaps it is that despite the fine control, you are really at the whim of the cards and it is actually quite difficult to go where you want to.  I don't have any trouble visualizing how the board will effect me, so it is only the cards that seem to thwart me.  I don't mind playing RoboRally, but I wouldn't pull it out unless there were a lot of players.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
While it has a cute theme and I want it to just be tons of fun, there is a surprising amount of skill to play. This means that  better players will quickly out pace poorer players. Our group almost always winds up ranking in the same positions barring terrible card luck. While cards are meant to add some randomness, they can just wind up frustrating as you never feel 'lucky' just unlucky. Game play improves with more players as some is more likely to be doing worse than you. Also supposed to be better drunk (which knocks skill component down) but irrelevant for our group.

The bots are cute, but there is no actual difference in game play between them (you could replace them with meeples) making it somewhat pointless.

While this game is supposed to be chaos and anything can happen, in reality its a game of bad cards and spacial manipulation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
One of Richard Garfield's games before Magic.  Preplan moves for your robot (move forward, left, right, backward, turn, etc) and attempt to reach objectives before your opponents. Weapons allow you to shoot or push other robots around.Some neat concepts, but the idea of pre-planned moves, then collisions with other robots, getting your robot shot in the back (though it has some appeal) gets quickly chaotic. I could stomach a short scenario, but a game that took 4 hours, with one person gaining better robot abilities really turned me off the game.

RATING: 6
This game always seemed like it should be great fun, but there's something missing for me. I love the mechanism of programming your move, and that taking damage 'locks' your moves so that you need to compensate. 

When we played, though, it never felt like a satisfying competative game. We found that the player who got out in front just kept their lead and won. We tried out all sorts of double-back tracks and house rules to try and keep the leader down, but it just didn't seem to work.

I guess others may have had a different experience with it, but for me this one always remained perplexingly unsatisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A chaotic game that can be a lot of fun with many players (especially six or more). This game is very unique compared to all other boardgames I have played; movement program cards are selected in order and then everyone reveals to see where each robot ends up. Can go for too long if the robots are not interacting or the board is too big. 

Gift to Andrew, SA.

RATING: 1
I've played games that were worse from a purely technical standpoint, but on a gut level, no game has aroused as much loathing and revulsion in me as this ultra-chaotic, headache-inducing nightmare.  The special weapons are unbalanced, there's a colossal runaway loser problem, you can sit and rotate all day long because you never get dealt any move cards, and it's well within the realm of possibility for a player to get eliminated 20 or 30 minutes into a game that goes on for another hour, or more.  The only blessing is that you can legally commit suicide and remove yourself from the agony.  There is absolutely no way I will ever play this again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Way too chaotic for my liking. Going into it, I thought it was supposed to be a serious, heavy game... my mistake. You have so little control over your actions if there are any opponents in your vicinity that you will do just as well randomly selecting your actions (which I proved several times in the game I played). Also, the powers, at least in the new version, are ridiculously unbalanced. The power that lets you get within one square of the flag (even diagonally!!!) should be removed for sure. A few others are way too powerful as well, and the lucky player that gets any of them can just run away with the game. After a few rounds, when I realized how completely random and silly the game was and I started playing for pure fun, I started to like the game better. I'd gladly play again, especialy knowing what I know now, but I doubt I would ever request it, and the original version with the expansion I found at a Savers for $2.00 is going to go on eBay soon! :)

RATING: 10
One of only three games in my collection that deserves the perfect '10'!

Hillarious theme and absolutely fantastic mechanics. The Movement Cards add a touch of randomness that make sure the game will never get repetetive no matter how many time you play. Everything still depends on the skill of the players though.
You program you robot 5 moves at a time, trying to avoid the dangers of the boards, as well as the other players.
Game gets better with each player you add, yet doesn't increase down time, since all players program and move their robots at the same time.

RATING: 7
I play this on and off, and I absolutely love the game. However, I don't feel I've played it enough to actually give it a thorough rundown. When I have, I'll get back to you.

You have to build the map properly. It has to be built in such a way that people who are trying to get to the first flag can still much with people going for the third or even fourth.

That said, my ONLY complaint about this game is the life system. Of course, the only issue here is that it really only affects new players, which is the sad thing. Once you have an idea of what you are doing and how to go about it, you shouldn't lose more than a single life in a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Everyone controls their own robot by placing 5 cards in their 'control banks' that vary from 'turn left', 'turn right', 'move forward one space' etc.  Everyone takes turns moving their robot with the goal of the game to get their robot to touch the different flags in order.  

With 5 or more players, the board gets really crowded.  With the nature of robot movement, how robots push each other and get in each others' way, it makes any strategy you have, inconsequential.  The game is fun, but for how chaotic it gets, Roborally tends to overstay it's welcome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It's a grid-based race game like Regatta with a pre-planned algorithm twist (a la Space Alert), two of my least favorite subgenres/mechanics. I think I dislike race games because they can last a long time (if the goalposts are difficult), the turns can get repetitive, it's chore-work-challenging (rather than fun-challenging) to keep track of your directional facing and directional movement, and they are boring. Nevertheless, this one is the best I've played so far in that genre.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Chaotic and fun. Don't be too serious with this one. The official rules are a bit broken, but with a bunch of house rules this is really good. The bad thing is that the game last a bit too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Enjoyment of this game, more than any in my collection, is dependent on the players.

There is a line in personal involvement in any game.  Somewhere between "invested in the game/win" and "not taking it too seriously" is the Platonic ideal.  If you've got a group of people in this zone, this game can be a lot of fun.  Inevitably, your well-thought-out plan will be disrupted by a slight bump in the road, a laser between the eyes, or your own bad programming, and as long as you can laugh with the weirdness this game is golden.  It's all about how you deal with the hiccups... and, of course, shooting your opponent's Twonky repeatedly in the back while on the same conveyor belt.

However.

If you get thrown out of gear by chaos -- and I know far too many gamers who do -- or if you must win at all costs, this game is not for you.  Furthermore, you'll drag down the fun of everyone around you.  The game drops to 1.5 if your game contains a single person like this, and even lower with multiples.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Good concept.  I just don't like spatial relationship games.

RATING: 8
It's a game that almost everybody loves. I played with several groups and up to now, pretty much everybody fell in love with RoboRally (more than me!).

It has a problem: when a player gets an early lead away from the pack, it's almost impossible to catch up, because there are accidents in the pack and the solo player goes unchecked for the win. This is solved by choosing the right course: a course that make people come back to the same área of the first checkpoints.

Also, I find that the card deck gets exhausted too often. The game should contain more cards.

Otherwise, it's a perfect game for certain moments. It is fluid and always create funny moments.

RATING: 8
I was totally blown away when I first played RoboRally at a game convention in 1995.  It was different to all those 'mainstream' boardgames I'd played growing up.  I was so impressed I went and bought it (1994 WOTC version) the following week.  So much fun to plan your moves in advance - and so much anguish as your robot gets bumped on the first register phase and you try to mentally calculate where it will end up.  It is a good idea to limit the time for planning moves.  You will find you can't help doing the "robot shuffle" as you turn your body this way and that to work out where to send your robot.  Great game! I painted the 8 metal robots that came with the game and they turned out really well.

RATING: 8
Starting this as a 7. I have only played 2 players and fully expect the rating to rise as I play with more, unless I don't enjoy the resulting chaos.

I really like how player-driven this is, which seems to be the case with many Garfield designs. In the vein of greats like Sackson, Garfield has created a barebones system where the players are playing each other more than the game. You read the rules to this and think, "That's it?", but it clicks when the robots hit the factory floor for real.

Updated to "8" when played with 7 and a short map. Hilarious and fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Although this 2-8 player programmable movement game plays fast and furious, even with higher player counts, some people might be turned off by the high degree of luck required to get the exact cards you need to execute the right sequence of actions on your turn. Additionally, it is easy for one, or especially two players, to practically make the game unplayable by intentionally going after others in an overly aggressive way instead of trying to get to the objectives like they are supposed to.

Even with the above criticisms, this game is an all-time classic and a blast to play over and over again with players who don't take it too seriously or become overly competitive.

RATING: 8
May take too long, otherwise great! Total brainlessness! Hillarious Robo-Rampage! Fantastic! If I'm behind, I often don't even bother with goals and flags anymore, I just run around harassing other players who deserve it (and if they can take it), or do other stupid moves, even if it kicks me ot of the game. You can easily do that in this game without being a jerk, believe me. 

It works only with at least 5 players. One should consider painting the miniatures, or using those of other games, because it's hard to distinguish them.

And one more very important thing: USE THE TIMER!!! Sometimes it seems best to start it at the beginning of a new round just to create stress and enforce mistakes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
our grp plays this game alot. it feels sooo good to blow smoeones robo up and even better after a couple of beers hehe
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was a big [i]Magic: The Gathering[/i] player, and naturally, I've heard of [i]Richard Garfield[/i].  And I also knew that he was trying to get [i]Robo Rally[/i] published before MTG.  So I wanted to play RR for a log time.  I finally decided to pick it up on an impulse buy.  It was the [i]Avalon Hill/Hasbro[/i] version.

I like the game.  It's fun and I like to play it.  But the quality of the components was [i]really[/i] disappointing.  The game boards are made out of the same type of cardboard with which cereal boxes are made.  And they are double sided so it's not possible to play each board with the all of the others.  Some of the components are nice, like the flags and the robots themselves, but they don't make up for the really cheap feel of the game.

I gave away my copy.  I would buy it again if it is republished and the quality is improved.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I like the mayhem factor. Personally, I'm not bothered by the randomness and lack of control. Hey, it's only a game, folks, and the idea is to have fun. But be forewarned: there is plenty of both in this one. I see this as a party game, preferably for gamers, or for those times when you can spring this on non-gamers and teach it to them. The more playing, the better, assuming everyone's okay with increasing levels of chaos. Players who like to feel they're in control of what happens are not going to like this. For yourself when you start, and for new players, use the easier boards and set-ups, because the harder boards can become quite confusing and frustrating. But once you start to get the hang of it, the game plays pretty fast, and, if someone gets analysis paralysis, you can use the provided 30-second timer to get them moving. On one hand, not as hard to figure out as I imagined; on the other hand, the usual beautiful Avalon-Hill-produced four-color rule book comes with ample illustrations that nevertheless leaves one with many questions about rules--stated or seemingly not. But these are not insurmountable hurdles. My 10-year-old son, Trevor (as of 2009) rates this game a "7.5". By the time Trevor was 11 3/4 (end of 2010), he had dropped his rating to "7."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Quite tedious in gameplay. Can get quite frustrating for some players who can't plan well. Need to figure out how to teach properly so everyone can have a great time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Magnificent!  Programming your robot, then watching him fall into a pit because things didn't go as planned... now that's my kind of game!  It's a good simple strategy game that involves well planning your turn.  Everyone else's turn directly affects yours and that often makes things very funny!  I like that there are a multitude of different boards, which creates in turn a multitude of different types of games.  Only one thing that bothers me... I wish the robots were more easily identifiable... I guess I'll have to paint them!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a great, great, great game! I have no idea why this one did not sell more, and as a result, went out of print. All the expansions are great, too. (They are selling on eBay for mucho dinero!) We have played 2-player games, but they turn into a slugfest, damaged and killed robots, and a slow game. If you are going to play 2-player, choose a variation. We use this one: robot-to-robot lasers are disabled, deal out 4 option cards to each player and choose 2 of those to start the game with, and when a robot is killed, it re-enters the game at the spot it was where it started on the turn it was killed. Now you have a real "race for the flags"! We have all the expansion sets and thus, many game boards to choose from for each and every game. I thought these were too expensive when I first bought them. Oh boy, was I wrong! A game well worth the money.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Chaos in a boardgame...I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I find the card deal too random and the execution phase too chaotic. If you get pushed one space off course, that can mean ending up on a conveyor or gear, and being 90 degrees out, so the rest of your turn is completely wrong. 

Some people think this is fun. I think it is boring. I suggest that the reason some people like this game is due to the emergent story-telling (and the wacky theme) i.e. unexpected, effectively random events that have a large bearing on your performance - but that stands in conflict with interesting decisions and skill. 

The game is just about acceptable if played on a single  board with checkpoints in sensible places. Otherwise it drags on forever. Executing the programming takes too long (so most of the time spent playing is spent implementing decisions that have already been made, not making decisons).

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
RoboRally is so cool and so different from anything that everyone needs to try this one sometime. This game can appeal to all ages and all levels of gamers. Get through the rule basics and setup; then the fun and magic begins when the robots finally move and the factory floors come alive.

The more players, the more the chaos and fun, but also the more length of gameplay. It's probably best to play with a timer.

Any edition is fine, but the latest edition probably has the most polished rule set.

I'm terrible at this game. I also find this too fiddly for me, and an incredible exercise in frustration.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love this game. It is a great puzzle game. There are many ways to customize the game with variant rules. Can be very chaotic so becareful when adding too many special rules. This game is fun with two players but is best with 4 or 5. Can play with up to 8 which is a deffinite plus, but more players means more chaos. The most entertaining part about this game is the humorous situation that happens when someone gets pushed or better yet, when someone makes a mistake. I often drive into a pit by my fault alone. People who don't like this game are usually the ones that have a hard time telling left from right and get confused easily by the shifting board. Others state that it is too random. True that you are delt random cards and occationally you will get stuck with a fist full of turn cards, but this is some of the fun. Just use them to shoot as many opponents as you can and make up the distance in subsequent turns. I really hate to see this game go out of print again and I wish they would print more expansions for it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Bought the new AH version on vacation, mostly because of the box and theme appealed to my son. Ended up enjoying it and the interesting mechanisms very much! Cool because you can play with so many players, has a very unqiue sequencing system for moves. Because it's hard to take it very seriously (in part because of randomness, in part because of the theme), we've had people jump in in mid-game, had others who've made no attempt to win just interfere with others, and had a wide variety of responses to it's play. It's amusing to introduce to serious gamers, who puzzle at it and take it too seriously. It is very chance drive, so you cannot get too hung up on winning, just ram around and have a good time! Kids will love the flashy look and cool plastic robots.

Update: Dropping to a 6 - this game is just too stinking long. With more plays I think this will go down lower. Novelty is wearing off...

3/06: It's a 5.

2/2010: It's a 4.
