Also the game can 'play out' to be very fun or semi-tedious based on luck and checkpoint locations.

RATING: 6
Humorous manual, nice artwork, I always tell myself I like this game, yet somehow it's never quite as fun as I'm hoping.  Part of the problem is that it's too difficult for most of my gaming group -- most of them aren't spatial and can't properly program the bots.  But even with good players, there's just too much unpredictability, volatility and, frequently, domination by whoever gets out to a good lead.  When so many places on the board kill you, running into another bot unexpectedly can be extremely hazardous to your health.

Still, I keep giving the game chances and suggesting it to likely prospects, so I think I like it somewhat...

RATING: 6
Interesting game that's sort of a logic puzzle -- you are racing your robots to flags while trying to avoid other robots and lasers while using rotating gears and conveyor belts to your advantage. Easy rules, but we found it a little difficult to get the hang of how to best use the cards to get where you want to be. 

I think it will be more fun once we have a few more plays under our belts and can think about disrupting other people's plans in addition to just trying to move the right way.

Despite losing the first game, D gave this a nine.

RATING: 7
Very cool puzzle game with a heavy dish of chaos to keep things more interesting (or frustrating, but I like a little bit of chaos). Still, chaos with 3 or 4 is a much easier pill to swallow than chaos with 6 or 7.  This game really doesn't scale well to 5 and up.  2 players is more of a logic puzzle, and you're playing the system too exclusively.

Some folks just won't want to apply themselves to what the game demands: meticulous planning, spatial comprehension, and, the frequent disrupting of plans because of (1) other players' clever play, (2) other players' mistakes, and (3) one's own occasional errors.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
A race game with a cool theme and a clever system of programming your robot movements.

Half the time is spent programming where you'd like your robot to go using a hand of cards. The other half of the time is spent watching the robots carry out those instructions. And when it all goes wrong because another robot nudged you, or because you simply made a mistake, the results can be hilarious!

The game is more chaotic (and for that reason also more fun) with more players, but can take quite a bit longer if there are too many. It is still fun with only a couple of players too, but you should expect less robot interaction & more of a focus on fighting against the track itself.

Careful track selection/design can help with these issues.

The AH 2005 edition includes loads of track suggestions, with handy ratings in categories such as "time", "number of players", "difficulty". There are even quite a few tracks with custom rules to keep things interesting & give ideas about how you might come up with your own challenges.

Components are great. The box is a little on the large size (just to handle the boards), but it is actually mostly empty. Perhaps splitting the boards into smaller sections would have helped here, and at the same time would have provided more options for creating tracks?

OWN: Avalon Hill 2005 Edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
This is a difficult game to discus as 'who' you play it with determines how good (or bad) the experience may be. The game itself is a tactical puzzle and can be quite challenging. With people that think/move quickly, this is an excellent game (a 10 rating). However, if there are 2 slow-pokes in the group then this becomes a tedious, torturous experience that never seems to end. One of the worst gaming experiences I have ever endured was a game of Robo Rally where the host for the evening convinced everyone that it was 'more competitive to play without the timer! (This particular game made a six player Risk game feel like a filler.) It is an excellent game with the 'right people'. The design feels similar to a Colovini game.

RATING: 3
3 - I love everything about this game except actually playing it, otherwise this would have been lower.

This game is infuriating and a nightmare and almost every game (save the one that had 3 players) ends the same, people get frustrated with getting shoved and bumped and shot and trapped and thrown in pits and they simply walk away from the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A race game to get to the checkpoints first. Each turn  consists of 5 programed rounds where you have to plot your course of action. Of course items on boards or actions of other robots will interfere with your program. A good way to get a level of simultaneous movement without a lot over overhead. It can be fun for a while to figure out the puzzle of how to take into consideration all the conveyor belts, gears... not to mention what the others are doing.
Nice change of pace to exercise your spatial talents.

RATING: 8
Anyone for some CHAOS???  That's what ensues when you play Robo Rally!  In this game players must successfully race their robots through a series of checkpoints by programming those robots with different cards.  What you think will happen rarely happens because other robots will push your's out of the way, into lasers, into pits, or off the board.  Don't get shot too many times or you'll lose a life.  This game can be a lot of fun with the right players!

RATING: 9
OMG so much fun :) I love this game. Programming robots and then moving them is supercool. Sometimes you can really juggle your cards to come up with something and quick. Sometimes you're lucky. Sometimes you just mess up with your spatial senses and end up in a completely wrong spot. Lot's of laugh, wacky "robot dance", player interaction. 

Register resolving is usually quite quick, don't see an issue with this. It's quick, it's frantic. Actually, game scenarios are brilliantly organized, so that you can pick up anything you like, for desired amount of players, time and difficulty. Also, it's a great sandbox game, that you can take and redesign in your own way, introducing new options, new boards or rules. Probably the second best non-party game for 6+ right after Eclipse.

And, oh, the hourglass included has a bloody red sand in it! So very cool!

RATING: 6.25
What I like about this game is that the randomness and luck factor is immense, yet it is still caused by tangible elements which are the other players. So whatever happens and no matter how much chaos is caused, it is not down to that untouchable mechanic but what the other programmers do. Thus, the randomness does not feel frustrating but rewarding if anything. On the other hand, I did struggle with the complex map a bit and while I do not mind being annihilated and outsmarted by oppenents, I found it a bit annoying that I had so many oversights and lapses. Of course, I see how this is the point of being a good gamer, but it feels to brainy and puzzle-like for me. Still a nice one.

RATING: 8
Awesome.  Best race game I've ever played.  Players who play enough go through three stages.  First is the noob stage when a player spends their turn just trying to visualize how their robot is going to move.  Second is the race stage where the players try to optimize their route.  Third is the interactive game where players play an offensive/defensive game of bluff and counter bluff while trying to optimize their route.

RATING: 8
Excellent race-and-crash/damage the other robots game. Nigh-universal appeal and plays well with many different ages (12 ) and types of gamers. Only drawback is the excessive time that bad hands can cause the game to drag on too long. It is tough to even get a 3-flag board completed in an adequate amount of time for what the game is.
[b]If time or patience is a concern, only play 2-flag maps![/b]
I can't understand why people would want MORE options, maps, or hazards to play on - the virtue of this game is simplicty and quick-play. If you muck it up with more hazards/difficulties, it would lessen the game's strengths.
Played many times online @ GTO, but not logged.

RATING: 2
One of my least favorite games of all time. The promise of the theme is great and I want to like it so bad, but the randomness and length of this one make it so tedious and boring. this game probably has one of the greatest disconnects between theme and the successful execution of that theme I have ever experienced in a game. This game should be frantic, funny, and fast, but it manages to be none of those things. A dull game of planning actions which ultimately don't matter, in order to meet very specific goals. Does that even make sense? Why would you design a game's goals to be so incongruous to the nature of the game's mechanisms? Terrible.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was the first board game I bought myself as an adult.  Having played Settlers a lot, I was looking to get something new and different for our group of friends to play, and being that I've always had an interest in robots, this game called to me.

I've played several small games so far and find it fast-paced, hilarious fun.  Picking your moves is challenging, especially with the time pressure against you.  Due to the randomness of picking cards, you often don't get what you need, forcing you to try to make the best of a bad situation.  Add in mistakes in visualizing what will happen and the inevitable unplanned run-in with another player, and this game becomes mayhem.  But even though it's mayhem, it's still fun.  People get a great laugh out of the silly, unexpected things that happen.

You would think the chaos would make the game unplayable, but because everybody is fighting the same problems, the game remains relatively balanced.  It ends up coming down to who can best visualize the consequences of their moves and who can find the safest routes around the board.  In spite of the randomness, skill and strategy are still an integral part of the game.

The boards are wonderfully illustrated and the characters are unique and lively.  The special ability cards also add an entirely new dimension to the game.

My only real problem with it is that it tends to be long.  For such a fast-paced game that requires consistently paying attention, even a short 3-player game is often an hour.  I'd love to play larger maps with more people, but the time to play grows quickly.  Also, doing the moves can be cumbersome, with people all reaching out at the same time and forgetting who has performed what steps.  I find myself having to play referee, asking each player their move and making the moves for them.

Despite the issues during game play, the people I play this with absolutely love it.  There isn't a lot of intentional conflict between players (though you'll see a lot of unintended run-ins), everybody gets a laugh out of it, and it's exciting the whole way through.

One variation I would like to try is having each person draw a random ability to start.  I find the ability cards never get a chance to come into play otherwise, but the players are always interested in them and wish they would come out more.  Perhaps handing them out explicitly would be a better option, giving everybody a varied play-style, without benefiting some more than others.

This game is high-speed, wacky fun. I really recommend it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun game of making plans--but boy, can those plans get blown off course quickly!

RATING: 10
I only discovered this game as a grown-up, and wish I'd played it in my teens.

If you allow yourself to just enjoy the sheer hilarity of people realising they've made the wrong move or that their carefully-laid plan has been derailed by someone ramming them at full speed then the game is a hoot.

I can see people's objections that they dislike making snap-decisions or being dealt an awful hand, but I've never enjoyed a game as much while doing so badly at it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very well-crafted and fun game that has attracted some reverse engineering of its system, thus unwittingly generating similar games. Nevertheless, it remains unique. The Program Cards and their related phase was a major contribution to the boardgame world, and also the game's biggest problem. Lack of practice creates a huge rift between newcomers and veterans, which can be frustrating to the point of embarrassment. It also has potential to create unassailable race leaders, thus lending itself to "finishing before the end"-type criticism. That said -- pick it up and try it out if you've never done so. An amazing game.

RATING: 8.4
Garfield has made a lot of games but there are probably only two he will be remembered for. Magic obviously. But Roborally was something really different. Watching as players try to wrap their brains around rotation (especially the body wriggle people do as they try to work out left from right).
If the game has a flaw it is that a skilled player will not merely win they will completely destroy the opposition, which can make the game a less fun when the disparity in ability is large.

RATING: 4
I played this for the first  - and so far only - time at my local club in December 2014. It's a game I'd known about for a long time and expected to enjoy - but I didn't. The first few turns of the game are just so random that it's easy - at least for a beginner like me (although it's not clear how more experience would really help here) - to lose all your lives before you really get anywhere. And then you have to sit out while all the other players get to the point where they can plan their turns relatively easily. NO game should feature player elimination if it can go on for another 2+ hours after a player is out. I simply went home early that night - not exactly what you want when you're looking for a fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
IMHO, the best board game ever.

We play this everywhere with everyone and no one complains. Great Board Game. a 10.

3 suggestions if you will play a lot:

1) get an automatic card shuffler. Yes, just for this game lol. This will save your cards from early retirement.

2) get a tray to organize the cards and pieces. We used a 1 inch thick tackle tray with locking lid from a department store fishing isle for like 2 bucks.

3) Paint your pieces super bright colors, with a marking for their fronts :) Avoid yellow, and especially black and gray, they blend with the board.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This is the worst game I have ever played.  Loathe doesn’t begin to describe how I feel about this game.Before I continue, note that I am not talking about component quality and all that – that stuff was fine.  This is only a review of the game itself.This game is a frustration simulator.So you’re looking at this game and it sounds kinda fun.  You play as little robots roaming around doing a relay race, fighting each other and trying to collect flags before everyone else.  Sounds fun, if a little boring due to there not being a story or even much of a theme, right?Well, then you start playing it and realize that the main point of the game is frustrating your opponents.  Ok, I guess that’s fine – other games have done that and it can be pretty amusing right?  At least it will be a fun mindless way to watch components going at it on the board, right?  Wrong.  The game is in no way mindless.  You have to carefully plan out 5 turns in advance on a constantly shifting board full of hazards and other players, where any one mistake can essentially take you out of the race entirely.  But you think, ok, well even if it is kinda frustrating and I have to plan out that far in advance, at least I know what I’m going to be able to do – at least we are all capable of the same moves, right?  Wrong.  You get a random assortment of cards to build your turn out of, and whatever the deck pukes out at you is what you have to deal with to do your carefully planned and maneuvers through a randomly changing landscape where any minor mistake can take you out of the game.  Fine, you might think, there are plenty of games where dealing with randomness is part of the fun.  At least in those games, everyone is equal under the eyes of the randomness gods, right?  Wrong again!  Depending on the setup, you might start out something like 20 spaces further away from the first flag than other players.  In a game where you move -1 to 3 spaces at once, and is a race, and has random card draw, and heavy planning, and take that.Ok, you think, but at least the other players are all in the same boat – it’s not like there’s yet another layer of the rich get richer going on, right?  Wrong again.  There are cards, which while difficult to acquire, give player powers so ridiculously powerful that they can just completely change the whole game, and make it nearly impossible to beat them.Ok, but there can’t be anything else wrong with it right?  Right?  Wrong, unless you like losing your turn and watching everyone else play.  A lot.  Fall off the edge of the map?  Lose the rest of your turns for the round.  Somebody kills you?  Lose the rest of the turns for the round.  Someone has a special remote control power card that takes over your vehicle?  Lose your turn for the rest of the round AND watch as someone else pilots your robot for you.  Make one tiny mistake?  Get stuck on a conveyor belt that takes you so far away from where you are going that you might as well not play anymore.Let’s say things aren’t going great for you – you made a mistake and went off course, and while everyone else is working on flag 2, you still need to get to flag one.  So you almost make it back when… someone kills you.  Now, if you’d ever actually gotten to flag 1 your could respawn there – a little behind but not out of the pack.  But you never got to flag 1.  So you have to go back to where you started.  You know, that spot 20 spaces further away from flag 1 than some of the other players.  Oh and that’s after losing all your actions for the rest of the round.You think, fine, well, whatever, at least it’ll be over and you can do something else after.  Depending on how much time you have, wrong again.  This thing is going to take 2 hours.  2 hours of random upon random upon hateful take-that upon uneven starting positions upon random and you are going to lose turns all the time.Oh, and lest we forget, on top of all that, you can get cards “locked” so that you never get to choose which command to enter for certain points along your program until you either die or skip your entire turn again.Maybe it’s just me though – the other players in the group seemed to like it a lot.  Maybe I’m just a sore loser who just doesn’t “get” it.  Honestly though, I never blamed the actions of the other players.  The game itself is a frustration simulator, so when someone kicks you in the balls when you are down, that’s really how the game is supposed to work.  They might even be doing it by accident.One of the players in the game said that it was a great simulation of programming.  He and I are both programmers, and I would have to strongly disagree, unless when he programs the following conditions are true: 1.	You only ever have access to 5 - 9 keys on the keyboard at any one time.  Many times this includes the arrow keys.  No mouse.2.	Those keys change every 5 minutes.  You always know what the keys are, but you have to deal with what you have.3.	The cursor moves randomly across the page due to powers you have no control over but if you are very careful and thoughtful you can predict.4.	You are competing with other people that have various parts of the program already done before you start.  5.	If you mess up, the program you are working on shuts down and it only autosaves every 20 minutes, and only then if you’ve reached some kind of minimum checkpoint.6.	At random you have to sit there and do nothing for 5 minutes.7.	Sometimes the keys get stuck and they will keep pressing on their own no matter what you do.8.	The keyboard spins around in circles.9.	You can’t get up for 2 hour stretches.  Ok so maybe that is better than actual programming :)10.	And finally, someone keeps coming up behind you and slapping you upside the head.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
As a player of WS&IM, Autoscooter, like the forward programming simultaneous movement aspect of the game.  However, players need to work to keep the analysis paralysis down and to keep the game moving forward at a somewhat brisk place.  Otherwise, everyone plays at the pace of the slowest player.  Furthermore, boards/goals must be set-up to promote interaction; otherwise, game can devolve into simultaneous solitaire.

RATING: 8.5
This is one of those games that is a great design, but in practice it gets tedious very quickly.  Yes, you can control how hard it will get from points A-B-C, but every time I've play this it wears out its welcome. Although not a great game, Wings of War is a better implementation of a similar mechanic.

Update: As long as you play with a lot of players and a small set-up (1-2 boards), and don't take it seriously, it's pretty fun.  But I do find it one of those games that some players often bail out early.

RATING: 9.5
Each round you draw a hand of 7 movement cards and have to use some of them to "program" your robot for the round.  Your best laid plans can be undone by the influence of other robots executing their program, environmental hazards, or your damaged robot that has stuck programming.

RATING: 3
I can appreciate the fact that a lot of gamers like this one.  I however, pretty much can't stand it.  I've played twice now, and both plays (designed to be short) took way too long and after much of that time I was no closer to the finish line than when I started.  Frustration level is high for me, and I feel like the game is stingy when it comes to getting behind.  I see no catch the leader mechanic, and more often than not the disparity in the special powers is annoying.
I'de play this again, but you'de have to plead, as I can think of about 200 games I'de rather waste the time on.

RATING: 10

Old edition:
Pit Maze: Very slow board, not one I'd rush to play too much.  

New edition:
Vault: Not as open as at first view; lots of options; quite a lot of clumping leads to lots of fun
Maelstrom: Always a fun map, because all the conveyor belts, but can be a bit predictable. 
Chess: Great open board, with lots of interaction.

RATING: 8
At one point I called this my favorite game, and also the game most responsible for bringing me into my board game hobby. Still very enjoyable and will always hold a special place in my collection, but is often frustrating for new players who can be prone to analysis paralysis or an inability to see their moves as they place them. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
RoboRally (AH 2005) -- Played original version once; four player. Played 2005 version once; six-player. Poor component and production quality of the 2005 version aside, this is a thematically solid game.

As it was the first play for four of the six of us, we played an "easy" set-up using only two boards. Big mistake. There was not enough room for six players to avoid one another. This led to a long, tangled game.

The thirty-second time limit for the final program is a must.

Implementation issue:  The card-corner index is missing the number (for straight arrow cards), so you must look at each card individually to determine your options. This is an inexcusable flaw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Initial rating after 1 play: 6 players, one simple room. Said to be a short game and it was 'just' 90 minutes. (Rule explanation took some time). 

The game is of that wacky *things go boom* and *plans go down the drain* type. Problem is that it moves slow - mostly because of constant need to check initiative order all the freaking time. Probably one only needs to check the move orders (and not turn orders). Interaction is there, but everything seemed so chaotic that the impression is more one of chaos than intentional interaction (then again we had that kind of room). With other maps, fewer players and so forth my impression may change - I read interaction gets more pronounced once everyone gets the flow of the game and understands how programming work. So, we'll see. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not bad for my first time out. Once I got the hang of it I was competative. Had I played a forward one or two I would have had a shot, increasing distance from the winning player to the last check point.

RATING: 8.5
I've never had as much fun losing a game as I have Roborally. I've seen a lot of comments about how other players' mistakes can ruin the fun, but for me and my playgroup that's part of the enjoyment. :) Couple it with some alcohol and you've a recipe for disaster (and a very fun one at that).

I would not play this with any less than six players, and preferably with the maximum eight. The more complex the board, the more chaos ensues. Which equals more fun (for me and my playgroup).

RATING: 7
Hatalmas partyjáték! A játékosok egy-egy robotot irányítanak egyszerű irányjelző lapokkal, amikből a robot sérülésének megfelelő számúval gazdálkodhatnak. Egyszerre kell lerakni minden játékosoknak előre megadott számú irányjelző kártyát, majd ezeket egyszerre kiértékelve elindulnak a robotjaink. Igazi káoszt okozva a pályán mivel ugyanazon ellenőrző pontok elérése a cél minden játékos számára. Az ilyen ellenőrző pontok körül óriási csődület alakul ki. Egymást taszigálják a robotok különböző érdekes felületekre. Ilyenek a sokféle szállítószalagok, a javító helyek, illetve a lyukak, amelyekbe az örök fémmezőkre kerülnek a robotjaink. A játék pozitívuma még a nagy játékosszám. Egyetlen negatívuma, hogy sajnos 3 élet elvesztése után ki lehet esni végleg a játékból.

RATING: 6
June 2009: Craziness and mayhem ensues when players start moving their robots as programmed. A bit random at times, but loads of fun. Rated 7.

Update (June 2017): Downgraded my Avalon Hill (AH) version from 7 to 6 after playing the updated 2016 version, which fixes many of the gameplay issues I have with this one. I always hated the locked registers and diminishing hand of cards (the new version replaces that with "Spam" cards), almost never getting any upgrades (the new version now fixes that with buying them for energy), the annoying streakiness of getting cards from a common card deck (the new version now fixes that with separate decks for each player) and the huge amount of room requires for it on the table (the new version now fixes that with smaller cards, player mats and maps). I even prefer the painted minis of the new version to the metallic ones here, so I see the new version as an improvement in every way, except maybe the lower maximum player count (lowered from 8 to 6).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Brilliant programming race that should be a lot more fun than it actually is.  This game is certainly not for everyone.  The gameplay can be a huge source of frustration for certain kinds of players.  For me, I dig it.  Most definitely not worth the price you have to pay to get this nowadays. Many fun elements, but the only thing holding back a runaway leader is the cards they get.  Next time I play checkpoints will have to double back on themselves so that players in the back can interact with the leader while still heading for their goal.  

UPDATE:  Two boards and three goals are all you need.  Any more and it just drags the game on too long.  When this is short, it doesn't outstay its welcome.  It is a great length and remains competitive (unless it doesn't, in which case it is over quick and you can start again).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love this game!!! The greatest thing about it: It can be played any way that you want! Out of the box its a race. Go from flag to flag the fastest while avoiding obstacles. This alone is lots of fun. Keep the board small and fun ensues. BUT!!! The mechanics of the game define movement and some combat. We have played our own scenarios which work SO WELL!!! Capture the flag, king of the hill, free-for-all death match, Teams, pairs, solos... This game is great...

One qualm, with the rules... The large deck of commands means that sometimes you will be left without options... Drawing 4 right turns and a u-turn is useless... I feel that the new redesign with personal decks will fix this. I may purchase extra cards to mimic this in my game. (but I hate the 6 player cap, 4v4 capture the flag is amazing!)...

And one last nit pick, the boards are so thin. They feel like cheap cardboard, and the tokens are so thin, they are difficult to pick up. 

So those two issues aside, this game would be an easy 10, we play it almost every gathering...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Fun game of competing mini robots trying to cross an area filled with obstacles and hazards (conveyor belts, rotating platforms, lasers etc).  This requires pre-programming your robot's actions using cards, but your careful planning can be disrupted by other players' 'bots bumping or shooting or otherwise interfering with yours at highly inconvenient times.  Nicely presented game, enjoyable by adults and kids alike - provided they can cope with a fair degree of chaos and frustrated strategy.  With the right group, it can be a hoot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I love this game! Very unpredictable and mad fun. All your well-made plans will get mixed up. There are many boards and scenarios to choose from.  It takes a long time to play - at least 2 hours - but it is fun the whole way through.

RATING: 1
I hate this game.  To begin, simultaneous programming isn't my favourite genre. I find it tedious. It fits the theme, except I don't care about the theme if the game isn't much fun, and RoboRally isn't. There's way too much downtime which is only exacerbated by the need to miss a turn every so often, sometimes twice in a row, and there may be nothing you can do about it. That's a lot of sitting and watching other people play. It's too chaotic to hold my interest and too long for me to enjoy the ride. And it's awfully boring once you know who's (not) going to win. As with demolition derbies themselves, I'm bewildered by RoboRally's following.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After a couple of plays, I've come to the conclusion that I really don't like this game.

One of the biggest problems I have with it is the length of time it takes to play -- it either drags on past the point where you're still having fun, or nobody is really making any progress on the objectives. Add player elimination to this formula, and it makes for a very dissatisfying combo. 

The random nature of the game creates some humorous situations but it's also a big hindrance. You have no control over the cards that you receive, so you'll experience many turns where you aren't progressing towards the objectives and might actually fall further behind (hence dragging the game on). Powering down your robot in order to heal damage essentially boils down to a "skip your turn" mechanic which is totally disengaging.

If RoboRally were a 30 minute games AT MOST, I'd be able to overlook its shortcomings and have blast (not really caring about who wins). Unfortunately, that's not the case and the longer the game takes the more its shortcomings are accentuated.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game was love on first sight.

First time I played it with some of my friends' friends. I was introduced to it as a racing game with kind of cutthroat mechanics and sort of randomness. Which didn't appeal to me much, cause you know, random things... not really my thing. But I was so surprised with it.

First off the theme is great. Robots racing cause their supercomputers are bored to death, love it. Then you have these gorgeous figures to represent your robots. On top of it each robot has a hilarious story behind it (Hulk is my favourite, it's just an awesome story). The board looks fantastic and you know what you're getting into on a first sight.

The first play was kind of a pain, because everyone except for me knew the game and they all played really fast (well at least that's how I saw it back then) and knew what they're doing. I struggled the first few turns, but when I got the hang of it... wow... I know it can be a little rough, when someone can't get to his goal, so he just tries to screw with you, but I don't know. In this game, I don't mind it because it's so much fun. I don't mind my robot being smacked, I find it to be part of the game. And you can also try to guess if you're even prone to being screwed over. I found out you can mitigate some of the random screwing by your oponents to think ahead and try to at least mitigate the danger when you know you're close to being smacked. Like when you're one space of a flag and there are 2 robots at your heels.

The only thing that made me a little suspicious were some people, who played the turn and then said "hey, why did you turn my robot that way? I was heading the other way." "Because you played left turn?" "Oh, I wanted to play right turn." Like seriously? Driving the wrong way? After that I saw those people turning around so that they knew exactly where the robot is facing and they could determine the right direction of the turn they want to make and it was just so funny.

I know it has some moments when you can get smacked up, but in this game, I don't mind. I still think it's a great fun and really I don't care who wins (even though I try to win every time I play, I'm not angry when I don't). It's a fun game to play and watch and I just love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Multiplayer Core Game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It took me a long time to finally play this older game and it was very enjoyable.

The programming that makes up the bulk of the game always seemed to me like it wouldn't be enough to keep me interested but when combined with the rest of the game it really does work.  You don't always have the cards to make something happen, even with 9 cards one player had to spend the whole turn walking into a wall because she had nothing but forward moves and one turn and the turn card would force her off the map to her death.  The laser fire is also a fun layer to the game, I took so much damage I had 3 cards locked by the end of the game (I was the Spin Bot and the cards were all turns so that seemed ironically thematic).

I think this game is most fun with larger numbers of players.  We played with 5 on a smaller map and nothing is more fun than when another robot's move throws a wrench in your whole plan...forcing you into a pit or something of that ilk.  I would love to play with the full 8 some time.

This is definitely one of those older games (coming up on 20 years old) that has held up very well over the years.  The mechanics are unlike anything else in my collection and it really does work well.

A friend suggested a battle scenario (I'm not sure if this is actually printed in the rulebook or not) where every robot only has one life and the point is to be the last robot standing.  Sounds like a lot of fun to me!

The last couple of times this game has been played it took WAY too long for what it is and is really hurting my enjoyment of it or desire to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
À l'entrepôt demandez qu'il soit installé sur les tablettes de l'Espace Sociojeux.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As long as you are expecting complete chaos in this programmable movement game, it can be fun. This is not normally my cup of tea, but my game group and I had a blast trying to get our robots to the check points while at the same time trying not to fall into the pits (either by accident, or by contact from another robot). 

This game definitely seems like it would benefit from higher player counts and goes pretty quickly despite having many players (as long as there is a reasonable number of flags). I didn't like the player elimination element, but if its a short course, it probably won't be a big deal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
BestWith:4>5>6_not7,8,3,2 [Programming, Racing]
Use small boards. Use a few optional rules in the articles. Timer: 30 second after 2nd to last player.

Variant: Armed & Dangerous Scavenger Hunt 2: Place option cards equal to the number of players at each flag. When a player scores a flag, the player to their right takes the pile and chooses an option to give to them. In this way, the stronger options are given to the players in the back of the pack, while the leader gets Circuit Breaker and Conditional. An even more anti-leader rule is to have the piles equal number of players less one, and not even give an option to the first player to score a flag.

Mark McEvoy: When mixing AH and WotC map boards, put an unused WotC board under every AH board, and vice versa. Then the play surface is all nice and level, with every board surface being the same distance from the table.

2009: Cards sleeved with 110 YuGiOh Clear Deck Gard Premium sleeves.
2014: RoboRally Options Deck from ArtsCow. (geeklist/40596/item/3421324)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
BestWith:4>5>6_not7,8,3,2 [Programming, Racing]
Use small boards. Use a few optional rules in the articles. Timer: 30 second after 2nd to last player.

Variant: Armed & Dangerous Scavenger Hunt 2: Place option cards equal to the number of players at each flag. When a player scores a flag, the player to their right takes the pile and chooses an option to give to them. In this way, the stronger options are given to the players in the back of the pack, while the leader gets Circuit Breaker and Conditional. An even more anti-leader rule is to have the piles equal number of players less one, and not even give an option to the first player to score a flag.

Mark McEvoy: When mixing AH and WotC map boards, put an unused WotC board under every AH board, and vice versa. Then the play surface is all nice and level, with every board surface being the same distance from the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
RoboRally is a chaotic racing game in which each player takes control of a robot, trying to be the first to reach a certain number of checkpoints. Along the way, however, players are bound to run into each other, unwillingly move off of cliffs, be shot by lasers and turned around by robotics so that they end up in places where they never intended for their robots to go. It is this element chaos that makes the game fun and a neat beer and pretzels game for up to 8 players. At the same time, however, it makes the game less suitable for an ordinary game night.

RATING: 8
Madcap fun, if you're not too serious about things!  I actually love knowing I flubbed the play, and instead of shooting to the flag, I'm going off a cliff.  One of my fondest gaming memories comes from this game, I'd taken a ton of hits, and my last 2 cards were frozen, and I was on a conveyer to doom. I managed to stay alive for three turns, eventually maneuver my way off the belt to shut down, then screwed up and drove into the same pit I'd so deftly avoided  for a few rounds.  Classic gaming fun!  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Not enough variety to remain interesting in the long run.  I honestly think the game could have benefited very well from the bots having different special abilities to give them some variety, because as it is, having different markers which are supposed to be different robots that act in unique ways but giving them all the same basic moves seems like a missed opportunity.  Why can't, say, Hammer Bot cause a point of damage if he is adjacent to another robot at the end of a move or Spin Bot be able to use a rotate card to rotate twice in the same direction once per turn?  Little touches like this would have given the game some character.

Ultimately, though, that's not such a big deal.  The real problem is that the game just gets boring before it's over.  Almost invariably you will find most players ending up with several bad hands in a row, unable to do much to stay in the race, while one or two players will get the perfect hand every time to zoom ahead.  Usually by the time someone has reached the second flag it's clear they are going to win.  Couple that with the extreme length of even the "Short" maps in the rulebook (most last us at least an hour and a half) and you get a lot of games abandoned before they are even finished.  I bought this game based on nostalgia because I remember playing the original version with my uncle when I was 6.  I guess you really can't go back...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very fun and relatively simple game to teach and play with non-gamers. Does have a glaring run-away leader issue.

RATING: 8
A classic game that holds up fine after all these years.  The most common complaints are that it is luck based, which is completely not true and that it goes on too long, which is a silly complaint.  You can make your own course, so just make short ones and this is not a problem.

It is very chaotic, so you have to like that style of game.  I think that it was one of the finest games made before 2000.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I played this with 8 people and it took almost 7 hours.  While there were things I liked about it  - mostly the planning and visualization of my long term route and my individual turn), this game is un-playable unless you put some sort of time restriction on the participants.

The boards also have graphics which show when certain hazards are active, and these graphics are difficult to see.  Additionally, with so many option cards and such a variety of obstacles there are way too many excursions rules (and then to the internet) to figure out what happens when Option Card Z meets up with Obstacle Q.

There aren't many games that I wouldn't play again, but I can't see another session of this in my future (certainly not without time restricting the moves).  The ideal time restriction for this game would involve something like a chess clock that would give everyone, say, 20 minutes total for all their turns.  That way, if you were in a complicated situation you could take a little longer to plan the possibilities, but you'd have to make it up later.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
You need a certain type of brain in order to enjoy this game, or at least an ability to visualize things a certain way.  But for those of us who can think like that, this is certainly a fun and unique, if slightly nasty, racing game.  A combination of great production value and a few simple elements that really bring out the theme certainly go a long way towards creating a life-like robot racing/battle experience.  And the vast array of set-ups and scenarios really makes for a very high replay value, no matter what size or experience level your group happens to be.  My only real complaint is that with only 2 or 3 players there is not quite enough interaction, but with more the playing time can drag out a little excessively.  GO SQUASH BOT!!  Game design: 4.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 4/5  Total: 8.5/10

RATING: 10
This game delighted us from the very beginning.  With a weekly group of six players, we had played Acquire backwards and forwards and needed a new game desperately.  This one got us right where we lived!  After 12 years of playing it, Robo Rally is a perennial -- screwed up only by the rules changes in the later editions, otherwise a classic.  The original rules with the virtual bots and laser fire are the essential, the extremely rococo option cards and silly boards for people who don't appreciate the heart of the game.  In our group we tend to design courses for 45-90 minutes; three flags on two boards is a typical approach.

RATING: 6
Like:
 Programming actions.

Dislike:
  All of the robot pieces look identical.
  Health mechanic immediately reduces the core mechanic of the game.
  Powering down is clunky.
  Terribly organized rulebook.
  A lot of lame options.

There is a good game somewhere in here.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[AH 2005 edition] {Robot racing; programming, simultaneous-action, modular-board, player elimination, fighting, partnership} RoboRally is an exciting game. It is full of player interaction, confrontation, intrigues and sabotage. It's even better with team-play mode, in which players have to collaborate together to achieve the goal. Turns tend to be fast. Player elimination may be a problem, if a player is eliminated early (but I think it's the problem of the player). It's also funny to see that some players always mix up the direction of turning and make himself drop in the pit or hit by the laser.

The game components are nice looking but it's very clumsy to paste the sticker on the flags.  There are enough scenarios for many plays. I think more expansions are coming.

RATING: 9
Richard Garfield made Magic, and then he turned around and made Roborally - this is a man with something important to say.  Robo Rally is a perfect execution of a game type that may actually be fatally flawed - the pre-programmed movement game.  This game is frustrating for the spatially impaired, and can suffer from other problems, as others have pointed out.  Nevertheless, when the players are all familiar with the game mechanics, it excels.

RATING: 2
Only played one game, but it was a complete farce. Now, Richard Garfield is a respected designer, but why one earth he designed a game with such a poorly designed feedback loop is beyond me. Beyond a certain point, the game descends into complete randomness as players can barely control their robots, needlessly dragging out the end game far longer than it needs to be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very cool game.  Those with computer programming skills possibly have an edge.  Can take a long time to play since it's hard to resist adding just one more board and/or flag.  One thing that, IMHO, helps the game immensely is the addition of a timer for laying down programming cards.  Not sure if this was a house rule or actually part of the Avalon Hill edition rules--I was playing someone else's set at a convention--but it makes the game faster.  It also makes it a bit more chaotic as people scramble to throw down cards in time, but chaotic has always been part of the Roborally charm.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Roborally is an excellent game with a mix of programming and maze crawling elements. Lack of downtime, speed of play, and intense immersion make all of these elements blend well together into a fun and engaging game. 

On the surface, the silent, heads down programming phase and the chaotic, uncontrollable movement phase looks bad. Don't be deceived. It is easy to remove luck from the game and prove that Roborally is a game of intense skill - and that the people that complain about luck simply don't get how to play the game. 

There are downsides though. The game could use a stronger catchup mechanism, and designing maps is really hard, and the game can be totally unfun on a bad map. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
This game is about programming the movement of your robot with a limited number of movement cards in order to navigate your robot through an obstacle course.  I thought this game would have a lot of potential.  I found that after a few plays, it was not as interactive as I would like.  It seems once someone has a lead or falls behind, there is not much opportunity to really interact with other players.  It feels almost like solitaire for a significant portion of the game.

I only played it with 3 people, so perhaps it is more fun with more.  At least with a low number of players, this game just doesn't do it for me.

RATING: 7
The "strategy" of trying to interact with other players and their bots, be it pushing or shooting them, feels too random since it depends on the cards they draw and place. The core of this game feels like you just set your own deck/path for your robot, and just see how the turns unfold. 

Otherwise, it's an enjoyable game. It's fun to see players miscalculate and run into a board element that completely throws their move sequence into disarray.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Buda
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Warning: Not for non-gamers. Not for people lacking spatial sense (my spouse). Not for people getting attached to what they have (as you'll surely die/get grounded/pounded/pushed into nothingness or simply get stuck at the wrong point (at a conveyor belt leading off the map during powerdown, for example)). Add in beer, and multiply those problems :)

That said, this is the very best game for 4 to 8 persons (yes, I own C&B too) wanting to shoot the hell out of each other or just give a subtle bump and see another bot going into the wrong directions... Why does it stand out? It's actually two games in one.
First phase, you'll be making your plans, laying them down carefully and anticipating what will happen. Chuckling in the thought you'll make things very difficult to some others, and feeling very superior about your perfect plans.
Second phase, you'll be screwing over other players (teehee), get screwed over (huh, what?) and discover you mixed up your program (oh no!)... Basically enjoying the chaos all around you :)

RATING: 5
I have had the opportunity to play this game twice now with a local gaming group.  Although I like the concept this game is too prone to analysis paralysis.  Yes, a timer can be used but then it favors those that are more spacially oriented than others (and yes - some people would have a hard time putting themselves in the eyes of their robots knowing what a right turn would do).  Overall it will either be a brain burner (to allow those that are spacially challenged to have enough time to think out their move) or very chaotic.

Absolutely an amazing concept, and I love the designer, his game magic has become an obsession of mine and King of Tokyo has been my #1 board game since I got back into gaming a few years back.  But all that being said, the largest flaw this game has is once you get behind, it is freaking punishing.  You might as well just quit the game.  Honestly it is frustrating enough I would bash many games over the head with this complaint, but Roborally has so many good laughs and such great theming I really can't hate on it too much.  If it wasn't for the sometimes drawn out length and effectively knocking players out of the game, this very well might be a 10 right beside King of Tokyo.

RATING: 7

The new version definitely improves on the old, as the faster boards make it possible to finish a game in under an hour.  Unfortunately, I think the cards just make it too luck-based/random to be really interesting.

RATING: 6

RATING: 6
A fun, chaotic programming game (Himalaya borrows the mechanic from this) with racing & fighting robots. My major gripe with this game is it's pretty heavy luck of the draw; you might easily spend two or more turns just turning around for lack of any movement cards, or first forcibly end up on a conveyor belt, then be sent to certain death on it, simply for lack of suitable cards to escape your fate. A bit less chaotic version of this could easily be a 7, even an 8.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Incredibly challenging, intriguing game of catch the flag where you must program your robot ahead of time and play out its actions, hoping that board elements and your challengers don't get in your way. It can be a surprising brain burner, but it's also hilarious and can work well as a party game. You're not allowed to think too much as there's a timer going on the slower players--which might be aggravating (we sometimes remove the timer when we're playing with my parents, for example). I especially like the detail of giving each robot characters its own quirks and personality. I've pretty much bonded with my go-to character, Twitch. Watching other players get turned around, run off the board, and power down only to be hit with lasers the entire time is a blast. It's definitely not for the easily overwhelmed, but for everyone else RoboRally is a great game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It is really fun, I just wish I had more players so I could do Capture the Flag and Warzone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A robot racing game which plays very quickly through the utilization of simultaneous turns and a timing mechanism which limits the duration of the planning phase. The experience is best defined as pure chaos due to the speed of gameplay and the multiple factors which can alter even the best-laid plans. Despite this game diverging from the mechanics of many of my favorites, which employ heavy doses of strategy and low amounts of luck, I find the game to be somewhat novel and entertaining. However, because I find the speed of gameplay to actually be somewhat stressful, I'd have to be in the right frame of mind in order to want to bring this to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
You certainly have to enjoy the chaos that ensues from the programming. You also have to be able to do well with spatial reasoning.

If you are fine with this then RoboRally is amazing. I love it! 

I think that the chaos is wonderful because it makes for some truly great gaming moments. 




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 1
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 1
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 3
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3


Overall - 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

The game can be frustrating with players who don't have the spacial reasoning to track their robots movement in their head.

Love the game though.

There was much we found frustrating in the older version that the newer one addresses quite smoothly. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Like so often, a brilliant theme is ruined by a game that is made mainly of flaws. Robo Rally suffers from a severious runnaway leader problem. The chaos produced by the different robots pushing each other, jammed progam slots etc., but the game drags for far too long to be justified by a good laugh every now and then, and since a player that gets ahead is hard to get caught up again, the game's often decided early, which takes out any tension.

Colt Express does the chaos through action programming thing far better, tighter, shorter, funnier, and produces more laughter will still giving more illusion of control to the players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Certian people will hate this game, and that is totally cool.  It plays best when treated lightly.  I can think of very few games that I would say are definitely better with alcohol, but this is way up there on that list :D

Oh one thing; if you've ever had a bad experience on this game, be sure to try it with a small board if you didn't before.  A lot of gamers go for big courses right away, but Robo Rally is better with a constricted field; cram a ton of robots into a small space and have fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
About [thing=18][/thing]:

[b]1) What is it?[/b]
An actions programming game in which players are represented by robots, whose objetice is to race to reach first some check points around the board. There are elements on the factory (map) that interacts with players, causing more mayhem and giving options and restrictions. And, of course, when talking about programming actions, there is plenty of room for chaos and despair, as when someone pushes your robot into a place you didn't expect and now your following actions can lead your robot to be destroyed!

[b]2) How do you play?[/b]
Is very simple: players receive a hand of cards (9 cards, minus possible damages on the robot) and must place 5 of them, in order, to be activated later on. There are Move 1, Move 2, Move 3, Turn Left, Turn Right, U-Turn and Back Up cards.

After everyone has placed the five cards on the personal boards, players will reveal them, one by one, at the same time. Every card has an initiative value, and the higher the numbers will activate first. There places on the board that do damage to the robots, or that move them around. Also, if a robot has its front facing another robot, it will shoot at it, causing damage.

The objective of the players is the reach all the check points, in order, first.

[b]3) Which are the decisions made during play?[/b]
What cards to use, considering the spatial positioning of the robots and the features of the board and also the initiative value of the cards to be used (the higher it is, more likely that you will use it first, thus having more chances of actually making what you want with it), in order to advance as quickly (and/or as efficiently) as possible, as [thing=18][/thing] isn't  survival game (even if players can be eliminated and robots take damage and can be destroyed), it is a racing game.

[b]4) What are the good things in the game?[/b]
- [thing=18][/thing] is a fun game, as it leads to situations that laughs will issue;
- easy to learn (the explanation took around 5 minutes);
- little overhead - the game is what it is, without additional mini-games;
- good replay value, as there are several ways to build the maps and even using the same map, but puting the check points in different places will change the way to achieve the goal;
- if playing without the upgrade cards, there is almost no in-text game, so language isn't an issue.

[b]5) Which are the bad news?[/b]
- It can drag, a [u]lot[/u] when playing with 6 or more players;
- if using a larger map, the play can easily pass 2 hours;
- there is player elimination, but is rare;
- no catch-up mechanism in a racing game means that you can lag a great deal behing without having real chance of winning (add this to the first and second bad news, and you got a treat for yourself!);
- there is some (not a lot, like that of [thing=31481][/thing] or [thing=38453][/thing]) stress in choosing the cards, since there is a limit time to it (after there is only one person still picking, a sand timer is used), but is a very minor problem, even for the players that don't like this sort of pressure.

[b]6) How do you feel while playing?[/b]
Like in a race without tracks. And also in a little war, as shots will be coming from several places. It is like Wall-E meets Rock'n Roll Racing, minus the track. And, by the way, a [thing=18][/thing] variant for Wall-E robots, with special power for each of the main robots, would be awesome!

Programming actions isn't the most simple of things when considering several possibilities, which makes stronger the case of playing with up to 4 people, as there won't be as many uncertainties.

In the end, [thing=18][/thing] is a fun game, with simple mechanics and no mini-games attached. It requires some control over player count and size of the map, but these are easy to apply. Not as stressful, tense or complicated as others games of programming actions. Therefore, I recommend it for families, light gamers and even hardcore ones.

RATING: 7.5
As a programmer by trade, I was very intrigued by this game when I first encountered it.  I was not disappointed because the game really does feature programming (rudimentary programming, but it's there nonetheless).  Determining the best possible path for your robot given the current accessible instructions (which are very often not ideal) creates the solid strategical thinking, while watching everyone's robots crash, shoot each other, and veer severely off course creates the goofiness and laughter that puts a smile on everyone's face.  It is a well-rounded game that I enjoy quite a bit.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not for mature gamers.  The mechanics were inventive when this was new, nearly two decades ago, but have been improved upon and incorporated into better games.  This one's runaway issues make it poorly suited to those looking for a finely-tuned machine.  As a party game, then - zany bonkers action, right?  Not really; here the lack of downtime and amount of concentration actually work against it, killing any chance of socialization.  And it takes too long for party games, at 60-120 minutes.

Suffers tremendously from runaway-leader /and/ runaway-loser.  
 
Once you get out in front, you have fewer robots near you - so you're less likely to take damage AND less likely to get pushed AND have better archive points.  
 
Deliberately going for archive points is counterproductive because they're often so far out of the way that it's not practical - and/or on the edge of the board, leaving you more vulnerable to the death you're trying to prepare for.  Once a loss happens, particularly before the first flag, you're penalized fourfold - you lose the rest of your turn, your position takes a huge hit, you get extra damage (itself a double penalty putting you closer to death AND making driving harder) AND lose hardware.  You might get away  from your competitors but this doesn't really help since you'll have to get near them again, from behind - and often it just means going against the flow of people returning in the typical relay-race flag configurations.

RATING: 4
07/2006:4

Used to want it, not anymore. I think this game represents some very terrible aspects of non-Euro games. First, runaway leader is a tremendous issue here. If you get killed early on and remain far away from the flag. Good luck to you! The second aspect of the game is how slow the game gets with more people, even on simple boards. If you are lagging behind...the game will drag you down even more. Thirdly, there is player elimination. I generally avoid those types of games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I got to play this for the first time at WBC 2005 (4 player).  I had read the rules, and knew how the game works, but I did not appreciate how easily things can go wrong.  I can also begin to see how important board layout is.  A couple of mistaken interactions can put you behind quickly, and you need to make sure that getting ahead doesn't also put a player in the clear.  I am also glad to see for myself that any complaints about game length are entirely self inflicted.  This game can be as short or as long as you want it to be.  Thank you Avalon Hill for re-releasing this game, even with mediocre quality components.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I've really wanted to love this game, the concept of it sounds like everything I would really enjoy in a board game.  High player counts, fun silly mayhem, robots, messing with your opponents... it just doesn't all result in fun for me.

I've played with 4 players, and it was decent, not a whole lot of interaction.  Played with 8 players and it was mayhem, but not really the good kind.  There was still not too much interaction, instead just a lot of time-consuming turns.

Each time I've played, it feels like it overstays it's welcome, everyone gets bored before the 4th flag.  It gets tiresome having to constantly move all the board mechanics.  There's always a runaway leader.  And there's always occasions where you get nothing but turn cards and spin in a circle for an entire round, or nothing but forward cards and you're forced to run off the board.

Also, feels like so many missed opportunities.  Would enjoy 3d aspects to the board, and more individualized robot characters, and more interesting ways to interact.

Just not for me I guess, sadly.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An extremely original and flat-out great racing game, with a madcap theme and sense of humor.  Peoples' two big complaints seem to be that it can take too long or that it has a runaway leader problem, and sometimes they're right, but, still, I love this game!  It just clicks with me: sitting there at the table, poring over my cards, studying the boards for just the right path, and desperately hoping another player won't screw it all up in a single card's movement.  Heck, just watching everything go wrong can be fun.  And for the naysayers, just use one or two boards at the most for your race, zig-zagging the flags back and forth across them, and I think you'll find far less of a problem with game length and runaway races.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Imagine that you're a supercomputer. Now imagine that you're bored. So you dream up a little contest for you and a couple of your supercomputing buddies. Your task is to move one of the stupid little robots out on the factory floor through a series of checkpoints scattered throughout the factory. The wrinkle, however, is that the factory floor is filled with all kinds of inconvenient (if not down-right deadly) obstacles located in various locations: conveyor belts, crushers, flame-throwers, pushers, teleporters, oil slicks, pits, et cetera. But the real fun comes when the robots cross each other's path, and suddenly your perfect route is something less than that...


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

1 play: 3 players

RATING: 7
Really good game - challenging for the brain (all those linear combinations of movements...), tons of fun, very versatile. You can make it a beginner's game with an easy board and a couple of flags or you can let all hell break loose on one of the more difficult boards. It's no problem if someone wants to leave or jump in in the middle of it, AP can easily be prevented with the hourglass, and if someone wants to make it into Robo-chess - well, that's fine, too, you ditch the hourglass. The movements resulting from a bad hand or too many damage points evoke hilarious cartoon-like images of robots repeatedly banging against walls and I don't think this game has ever been played without anyone starting to eventually produce sound effects. The only tiny flaw is that if you take it too seriously you might get frustrated with the randomness of the cards you get dealt.

RATING: N/A
Imagine that you're a supercomputer. Now imagine that you're bored. So you dream up a little contest for you and a couple of your supercomputing buddies. Your task is to move one of the stupid little robots out on the factory floor through a series of checkpoints scattered throughout the factory. The wrinkle, however, is that the factory floor is filled with all kinds of inconvenient (if not down-right deadly) obstacles located in various locations: conveyor belts, crushers, flame-throwers, pushers, teleporters, oil slicks, pits, et cetera. But the real fun comes when the robots cross each other's path, and suddenly your perfect route is something less than that...

RATING: N/A
Avalon Hill

Shrinkwrapped
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the boardgame version of Robot Wars. There are pushers, pits, and bot on bot violence. Everything cool about the T.V. show is here. I wonder if anyone is owed some endorsement money?

I have the 2005 reprint of RoboRally from Avalon Hill...err...Wizards of the Coast. It comes with eight plastic robot models, two decks of cards, four game boards, a sand timer, and a couple of sheets containing tokens and player aids. While nothing is terribly wrong with the components, the cards seem a little flimsy and the double sided gameboards are really just thick pieces of cardboard. It all feels a little cheap, considering the $40 to $50 price of the game.

This is certainly a love it or hate it game. It takes quite a bit of planning and predicting, as well as a strong sense of spatial relations to keep your robot from running in circles. Of course, since you plan your moves 5 turns in advance from a random distribution of cards, going in circles is sometimes your best option! To make matters worse, one little bump from an opponent's bot can make your little guy end up half way across the board from where you had planned. Early in the game this is hilarious. Three hours in...it can be maddening.

Essentially, RoboRally is all about making order out of chaos. This makes the game challenging and sometimes a bit frustrating. The core mechanic of programming your robot's movement is pretty ingenious, and  gives the game a bit of a puzzle feel. While this is great in terms of actual gameplay, the reality is that the game can become quite intense. Maybe too much so. This is not a very social game, as it takes piles of concentration to make any progress. It can be quite draining over the few hours it takes to play. Sometimes it can devolve into a complete buzzkill, with everyone burnt out on gaming for the day...after one game. I don't feel this is really a design issue, it is simply a demanding game by nature. At the very least, it is something that should be considered before it hits the table with your game group.

Personally, I love the idea of this game more than actually playing it. I think the mechanics are nifty, and I love it when everyone gives up racing early in the game and starts trying to destroy each other. That being said, there is a lot about this game that makes me feel like I am solving logic puzzles rather than relaxing with my friends. I also have yet to play a game where half the field wasn't out of the race two hours in. Inevitably, those players either get extremely antsy or worse yet, annoyed. This leads to disinterested, random card play or unnecessary combat that tends to stop anyone from winning. As a result, the game goes on even longer, amplifying the effect. This flaw is due more to human nature than to the design itself, so I don't really hold that against it. I am just very careful about when and to whom I offer it up.

--
Update (2015): Twin Tin Bots is the game I really wanted RoboRally to be: It has much more direct interaction since it's based on competing for the same resources, rather than racing. And the programming mechanic (changing one instruction at a time on one of two bots) is both faster and more interesting than RoboRally (create a program from a random hand draw). Love Twin Tin Bots, will trade RoboRally.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game!  I've been hooked on it since I read the first review, and I play it every chance I get -- which isn't too often, sadly.

With so many great games out there, and so many different types of games, it's virtually impossible for me to choose just one game as my All-Time, Number One Favorite Game.  But if I HAD to choose just one, Robo Rally would be it.

I particularly like how there is so much variety to how to set up the boards and how to set up the flags (not to mention the variety between the different boards themselves).  A simple adjustment in board or flag placement will have a large effect on the difficulty of the game.

Also, the game mechanic of being issued a limited number of cards to program your robot for the next 5 phases is a very good one.

As a bonus, I've found that it's very easy for people new to the game to learn the rules and join in ... and give the veterans a run for their money.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is a sentimental favorite of mine.  We seldom play it because our wives hate the left brain workout figuring out how to coordinate the program cards with their positions on the board.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Easy to learn the basic gameplay, but can be difficult to visualize the robot's moves in advance when the board has multiple obstacles.  The game becomes more fun with more players, because there is more chaos.  In fact, this game with 5 or more is guaranteed to produce laughs because the unpredictable will happen!  And really, the fun part is when someone inevitably screws up -- that's really the random part of the game, because it could just as easily help you as kill you...  If someone asked me what is the best game for 7-8 players, I would definitely say RoboRally!

It would seem that a lot of luck is involved with the draw of the cards, but it doesn't play that way - in our group, the best players always win.  

A downside with the game is that you do need at least 4 players, and I would even hesitate to play it with just 4 - but add a 5th player and I would never turn down this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fast-paced and very fun - one of my favorite games of all time.  It has a near-perfect mix of luck and strategy, plus loads of player interaction.

With two or three players this is mostly a racing game, but the more people you add (up to eight out of the box) the crazier things get.

It has four different (double-sided) boards and eight flags, which provides countless course layouts above and beyond the premade ones shown in the rulebook.  Depending on how many flags you place and where you put them you can make the game as long or as short as you want.  Using all of them will end up being way too long unless they're in relatively "easy" positions, but 3 or 4 is usually pretty good for a small map and 2 or 3 is good for a larger (multi-board) layout.

The programming aspect can be a bit frustrating to players that have a hard time visualizing where their robot will end up at the end of each register, but after a few turns most people should get the hang of it.    It comes with a timer if AP or excessive slowness is a problem, but we've never used it because it tends to just penalize players who are already having a hard time with the game.

We use two house rules:
1)  The Mechanical Arm option/upgrade is removed from the deck [i](it's *way* too powerful if someone gets it early in the game or if it's a difficult course)[/i]
2)  If a player is dealt a hand made up of only straight moves or only rotates, they can call a "mulligan" and get dealt a whole new hand.  [i](This way no one can say they got screwed by a bad hand.)[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My biggest problem with playing RoboRally is that I'm dyslexic and I frequently get my left and right confused.
If I can convince others I always want to play.  I imagine that if I played it everyday this could change but I don't see this happening.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

game time worth it: 7/10

If you can find a first ed though, i highly recommend it. 

10 - Outstanding.
9 - Excellent.
8 - Very good.
7 - Good.
6 - Fair.
5 - Average.
4 - Below average.
3 - Poor.
2 - Very poor.
1 - Defies description of a game

RATING: 6
Had been interested in this game on premise, but in playing it...uggh.  The thing is that there is no real randomness during a turn, so you'd THINK that the game would be about planning very well - and that sometimes does pay off, and when a particular chain of events flows well it's fantastic - but then someone comes flying in from some other angle for inexplicable reasons, bumps you one square, and now your carefully-planned sequence of moves has you soar off the board instead of catching a flag.

Of course, while there is no real randomness DURING a turn...yeah, setup can be a pain.  Try accomplishing anything with no turn cards... :-/

I dunno, not really a fan of this one.

RATING: 5
Really needs to be a computer game. The concept is excellent, but there isn't enough interaction with few players, and it takes too long when you have many. Also, it really should be a game about clever tactics and anticipating others' moves, but in my experience mostly comes down to who can go the entire game without making a blunder cause they e.g. put a Turn Left when they meant to put a Turn Right.

Both the length and the blundering aspects would be fixed by a computer version that did move resolution for you and offered a preview of what your move is going to look like (assuming no interference from others) before you commit it.

RATING: 2
I've played it once and I'll never play it again. You're manoeuvring your robots on auto-pilot 'till Lady Unfortunately decided that another played had to bump you in a hole or a laser beam so you would have to start all over again. Bad, bad, bad and frustrating.

UPDATE: Changed my rating from a 3.5 to a 2. Played it once more after all because there was no other game going on. Sigh... Less than 30 minutes in I regretted it... You're simply way too dependent on the cards you get dealt. And you get fewer cards as your wounds stack up, making it only worse. Some people may find that amusing, I found it extremely frustrating. I'm not a control freak by any means, but come on... Not being able to cross conveyor belts because you only get cards that let you turn or take 1 step? Wasted turn, huzzah! And you can't do anything about it. Not good in a racing game. Will absolutely never play this again.

RATING: 1.5
Utterly and completely loathe this game.  would rather have me face smashed in by a wooden plank than sit through this again.

I use the term 'game' loosely.  I felt more like a spectator than a player.  It's like a slot machine or something; pull the handle and watch the thingy go round.  I am abosultely convinced you either have to be terribly drunk or have big watermelon brain to get any enjoyment out of this.

The others with me the few times I played loved it - really, it's just so bizzare that some give this a 10.

If you're a eurogamer - you'll HATE it. Passionately.

But for some reason, if you're a 100% total nerd; the monty python quoting genuine article, the real sterotype of the hollywood nerd, you'll likely love it.  I have no idea why, but that seems to be how it works.

RATING: 7
Amazing when it first hit the scene, but appears a bit clunky and unwieldy compared to silky-smooth eurogames. A game where the concept and potential fun are greater than the implementation and actual fun. Novel ideas, brain-burning decisions and planning, and a great time to be had with the right group. Lends itself to overanalysis and programming can take forever, but the new edition addresses this with a countdown clock once players start to complete their programmed actions. Problem might be finding enough others that agree this is a good way to spend an evening.

RATING: 8

Edit: Most recently, we have tried a variant on our Ricochet Robots board.  It didn't work too well.

I would say that this game really needs to be played with more than just two people.  Otherwise, you end up with a runaway leader problem that cannot be avoided.

This game works best when everybody is willing to have fun, (eg laughing at the misfortunes of the robot that is getting hammered even if it is their own robot).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
On a chaotic board full of walls, holes, lasers and conveyor belts, make a 5-card program for your robot to try to get closer to the checkpoint. Robots push and shoot and mess up eachother's programs in this hilarious superduperclassic. Absolute all-time favourite. Play time can be adjusted from 30 minutes to infinity, depending on how long track you make.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I actually have the 2005 reprint of this, but it wasn't in the list. As yet unplayed, but with the right quantity of players (4+) I can see it being great, chaotic fun.

Edit: Played this and it is no longer for trade. What did it for me was the simplicity of it. It's super easy to explain to a large number of people - all the cards do exactly what it says on them and there isn't an overwhelming amount of board elements on the easy maps. Definitely play with only 3 flags and one map though, or this will drag on horribly.

RATING: 6
Based on Avalon Hill edition

Nice, manic race game, with a definite sense of panic as you desperately try to figure out your moves before the last grains of sand drop from the timer.  Its a bit long for a 'lite' game though, which is a shame.
Also, not enamoured with the flag pieces either.  Couldn't they have printed the numbering on them instead of using stickers...

RATING: 7
